revision.text:
{{good article}} {{short description|Archaic and derogatory baseball term for a home run that barely clears the nearest outfield fence}} [[File:1954 World Series game two.jpeg|thumb|right|The short right field fence at the Polo Grounds|alt=A black and white image of right field and first base in a baseball diamond in a large stadium with filled stands. A runner is rounding first.]] In [[baseball]], a '''Chinese home run''', also a '''Chinese homer''', '''Harlem home run''',<ref name="Teaching Tolerance">{{cite web|title=Origins: A simple word game for use in human relations trainings|url=http://www.tolerance.org/sites/default/files/documents/wordorigins_upper_handout2.pdf|publisher=[[Teaching Tolerance]]|page=6|accessdate=March 17, 2015}}</ref> or '''Pekinese poke''',<ref name="Dickson definition">{{cite book|last=Dickson|first=Paul|title=The Dickson Baseball Dictionary|date=2011|publisher=[[W.W. Norton & Co.]]|location=New York|isbn=9780393073492|pages=182–84|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ceeU7xSLw5kC&pg=PA182|edition=3d|editor=Skip McAfee|accessdate=March 10, 2015}}</ref> is a derogatory and archaic term for a hit that just barely clears the [[outfield]] fence at its closest distance to [[home plate]]. It is essentially the shortest [[home run]] possible in the ballpark in question, particularly if the park has an atypically short fence to begin with. The term was most commonly used in reference to home runs hit along the [[right field]] [[Glossary of baseball terms#foul lines|foul line]] at the [[Polo Grounds]], home of the [[History of the New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]], where that distance was short even by contemporary standards. When the Giants moved to [[San Francisco Giants|San Francisco]] in 1958, the [[Los Angeles Coliseum]], temporary home of the newly relocated [[Los Angeles Dodgers]], gained the same reputation for four seasons until the team took up residence in its permanent home at [[Dodger Stadium]] in 1962. Following two seasons of use by the [[expansion team|expansion]] [[New York Mets]] in the early 1960s, the Polo Grounds were demolished, and the term gradually dropped out of use.<ref name="Dickson definition" />
Why these home runs were called "Chinese" is not definitely known, but it is believed to have reflected an [[Stereotypes of East Asians in the United States|early 20th-century perception]] that [[Chinese American|Chinese immigrants]] to the United States did [[History of Chinese Americans#Indispensable workforce|the menial labor they were consigned to with a bare minimum of adequacy, and were content with minimal reward for it]]. A [[Tad Dorgan]] cartoon has been proposed as the likely origin, but that has not been proven; the earliest known use is in a 1927 newspaper account of a [[Pittsburgh Pirates]]-[[Philadelphia Phillies]] game. In the 1950s, an extended take on the term in the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' led [[Chinese in New York City|the city's Chinese-American community]] to ask sportswriters not to use it.<ref name="Bill Madden book">{{cite book|last1=Madden|first1=Bill|authorlink=Bill Madden (sportswriter)|title=1954: The Year Willie Mays and the First Generation of Black Superstars Changed Major League Baseball Forever|date=2014|publisher=[[Da Capo Press]]|isbn=9780306823329|page=242|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6vMdBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA242|accessdate=March 12, 2015}}</ref> This perception of ethnic insensitivity has further contributed to its disuse.<ref name="SB Nation post">{{cite web|last=Neyer|first=Rob|title=Seven things you can't say on (baseball) television|url=https://www.sbnation.com/2013/5/8/4312552/dirty-words-baseball-television-george-carlin|publisher=[[SB Nation]]|date=May 8, 2013|accessdate=March 10, 2015}}</ref>
It has been [[usage|used]] to disparage not only the hit but the batter, since it implies minimal effort on his part. Giants' outfielder [[Mel Ott]], who hit many such home runs in the Polo Grounds during his career, was a frequent target of this as his physique and unusual batting stance were not those associated with a [[power hitter]]. The hit most frequently recalled as a Chinese home run was the three-run [[pinch hit]] [[walk-off home run|walk-off shot]] by [[Dusty Rhodes (outfielder)|Dusty Rhodes]] that won the first game of the [[1954 World Series]] for the Giants on their way to a sweep of the [[Cleveland Indians]].
A secondary meaning, which continues today, is of a [[foul ball]] that travels high and far, often behind home plate. However, this appears to be confined to [[sandlot baseball|sandlot]] and high-school games in [[New England English|New England]]. Research into this usage suggests that it may not, in fact, have had anything initially to do with Chinese people, but is instead a [[corruption (linguistics)|corruption]] of "Chaney's home run", from a foul by a player of that name which supposedly won a game when the ball thus hit, the only one remaining, could not be found.<ref name="Dickson definition" />
==Etymology== {{wiktionary|Chinese home run}} As early as the late 19th century, baseball players and fans had recognized that parks with shorter distances to the foul poles and back fence allowed for home runs that were regarded as undeserved or unearned, since [[Batted ball|fly balls]] of the same distance hit closer to or in [[Baseball field#outfield|center field]] could easily be caught for [[Out (baseball)|outs]]. In 1896 Jim Nolan of the ''[[The Daily News (Texas)|Daily News]]'' of [[Galveston, Texas]], reporting on the expansion of the local ballpark, wrote: "The enlarged size of the grounds will enable the outfielders to cover more ground and take in fly balls that went for cheap home runs before. Batsmen will have to earn their triples and home runs hereafter".<ref name="ADS O'Toole post">{{cite mailing list|url=http://listserv.linguistlist.org/pipermail/ads-l/2010-November/104287.html|title=And in (additional) honor of the Giants' World Series win... |date=November 4, 2010|accessdate=March 12, 2015|mailing-list=ADS-L|last=O'Toole|first=Grant}}</ref> In 2010 Jonathan E. Lighter, editor of the ''[[Historical Dictionary of American Slang]]'',<ref name="UTK news Lighter page">{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Slang|url=https://news.utk.edu/1992/04/28/slang/|location=[[Knoxville, Tennessee]]|publisher=[[University of Tennessee]]|date=April 28, 1992|access-date=April 18, 2018}}</ref><ref name="HDAS Google Books page">{{Cite book|title=Random House Historical Dictionary of American Slang: H-O|url=https://books.google.com/?id=dKEYAAAAIAAJ|accessdate=April 18, 2018|isbn=9780679434641|last1=Lighter|first1=Jonathan E.|date=1997-01-01}}</ref> posted on the [[American Dialect Society]]'s (ADS) [[listserv]] that he had found the earliest use of the term "Chinese home run" for that type of hit in a [[Charleroi, Pennsylvania]], newspaper's 1927 account of a [[Philadelphia Phillies]] game against the [[Pittsburgh Pirates]]: "The Phillies went into a deadlock on [[Cy Williams|Cy]]'s Chinese homer only to see the Buccos hammer over four runs a little later."<ref name="Lighter ADS post 1">{{cite mailing list|url=http://listserv.linguistlist.org/pipermail/ads-l/2010-November/104275.html|title=And in (additional) honor of the Giants' World Series win... |date=November 3, 2010|accessdate=April 18, 2015|mailing-list=ADS-L|last=Lighter|first=Jonathan}}</ref>
This predates by three years the earliest use that [[Paul Dickson (writer)|Paul Dickson]] found when researching ''The Dickson Baseball Dictionary''. In a 1930 ''[[Washington Post]]'' story, writer Brian Bell quoted [[Dan Howley]], [[manager (baseball)|manager]] of the [[Cincinnati Reds]], defending the hitting prowess of [[Harry Heilmann]], who was then finishing his career under Howley. "[They] were real home runs", Howley said, pointing out how far from the field they had landed. "They were not Chinese home runs in that short bleacher at right", referring to the back fence on the foul line at the [[Polo Grounds]], a mere {{convert|258|ft}} from home.<ref name="Dickson definition" /> [[File:Thomas A. Dorgan.png|thumb|200px|left|Cartoonist [[Tad Dorgan]] may have popularized the term.]] Dickson reiterated the results of two attempts in the 1950s to determine the term's origin, following its widespread use in stories. After Rhodes' home run, Joseph Sheehan of ''[[The New York Times]]'' made the first attempt. His research took him to Garry Schumacher, a former baseball writer then working as the Giants' press relations executive, who had himself been known for creating some baseball terms that went into wide use. Schumacher told him that he believed [[Tad Dorgan]], a cartoonist popular in the early decades of the 20th century, had introduced it, probably in one of his widely read ''Indoor Sports'' [[Panel (comics)|panels]].<ref name="Dickson definition" /><ref name="NYT Sheehan 1954 article">{{cite news|last=Sheehan|first=Joseph|title='Chinese Homer': How it All Began|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1954/10/01/85661677.html?action=click&contentCollection=Archives&module=ArticleEndCTA&region=ArchiveBody&pgtype=article&pageNumber=29|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 1, 1954|accessdate=April 18, 2018}}</ref> It has, however, been suggested that Dorgan disliked the Giants and their manager, [[John McGraw]], which may have also given him a reason to coin a disparaging term for short home runs<ref name="Baseball Bits">{{cite book|last1=Schlossberg|first1=Dan|title=Baseball Bits|date=2008|publisher=[[Penguin Books]]|isbn=9781440630002|page=185|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hBw9uWwLxSoC&pg=PA185|accessdate=March 12, 2015}}</ref> (however, Lighter said in a followup post to the ADS listserv that he had found no evidence Dorgan coined the term, or even that the cartoonist had heard it<ref name="Lighter ADS post 2">{{cite mailing list|url=http://listserv.linguistlist.org/pipermail/ads-l/2010-November/104277.html|title=And in (additional) honor of the Giants' World Series win... |date=November 3, 2010|accessdate=April 18, 2018|mailing-list=ADS-L|last=Lighter|first=Jonathan}}</ref>).
During the 1910s, when Dorgan's cartoon was at its most popular, there was an ongoing debate over the [[Chinese Exclusion Act]], the first immigration law in U.S. history to bar entry to the country on the basis of ethnicity or national origin.<ref name="Chinese Exclusion Act">{{cite web|title=Chinese Exclusion Act (1882)|url=https://www.ourdocuments.gov/doc.php?flash=true&doc=47|publisher=[[U.S. National Archives]]|accessdate=February 2, 2018}}</ref> Chinese immigrants who had entered prior to its 1882 passage remained, however, and were often hired as "[[coolie]]s", doing menial labor for low pay. "The idea was to express a cheap home run as Chinese then represented what was cheap, such as their labor", [[lexicography|lexicographer]] [[David Shulman]] told Dickson.<ref name="Dickson definition" /> This was in keeping with a bevy of other contemporary such usages, such as calling a [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] automobile a "Chinese [[Rolls-Royce Limited|Rolls-Royce]]". Sheehan also wrote that it carried the additional "connotation of a homer of little account."<ref name="NYT Sheehan 1954 article" /> He did not think that Dorgan, known for the gentleness of his [[satire]], had meant it to be insulting, especially since he had two [[international adoption|adopted sons from China]].<ref name="Dickson definition" />
In 1958, when the [[San Francisco Giants|Giants moved to San Francisco]] and left the Polo Grounds, [[J. G. Taylor Spink]], publisher of ''[[The Sporting News]]'', made another attempt to find the source of the term. He agreed with Sheehan that it had originated with Dorgan and the association of Chinese immigrants with cheap labor. However, his article was reprinted in the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', and readers there wrote in with alternative suggestions.<ref name="Dickson definition" />
One was from Travis McGregor, a retired San Francisco sportswriter. In his recollection, the term had been in use on the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] in the years just before World War I. He attributed it to a joke derived from an aspiring Chinese-American sportswriter covering [[Minor League Baseball|minor league]] games in the [[Pacific Coast League]], whom the typists at newspapers simply credited as "Mike Murphy" since they couldn't properly [[transcription (linguistics)|transcribe]] his name. "He had a keen sense of humor, a degree from [[Stanford University|Stanford]] and a great yen to be a newspaperman", McGregor wrote in his own letter to ''The Sporting News''. As a result of his education, he spoke with no accent, but still used affected [[syntax]]. "He was a one-man show at baseball games ... for two or three seasons, an Oriental [[Fred Allen]]", according to McGregor. Once, he recalled, Murphy described one batter as "wave at ball like [[Mandarin (bureaucrat)|Mandarin]] with fan".<ref name="Dickson definition" />
This phrase stuck in the minds of the other sportswriters in attendance and, McGregor suggested, it spread among all the league's writers, becoming a [[catch phrase]]. "The old Oakland park's short fence caught the most of it from Mike, and his 'Mandarin fan' waving balls out of the park were knocked back to 'Chinese homers'", said McGregor. A number of Murphy's comments were adapted into cartoons by Dorgan, a native of San Francisco, and from there the term migrated into print. McGregor believed that either Ed Hughes or Harry Smith of the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' were the first to do so, and better-known writers like [[Ring Lardner]] and [[Damon Runyon]] may have picked it up from them and popularized it nationwide.<ref name="Dickson definition" />
Sportswriters extended the idea. Shulman wrote in 1930 of hearing them talk about short [[pop fly|pop flies]] as "Chinese [[line drive]]s".<ref name="Dickson definition" /> [[Texas leaguer]]s, or high bloop [[single (baseball)|singles]] that fell between the [[infield#baseball|infielders]] and outfielders, were likewise called "Japanese line drives" when hit in [[Pacific Coast League]] games.<ref name="Dickson 466">Dickson, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ceeU7xSLw5kC&pg=PA466 466].</ref>
There have been other theories to explain how home runs that barely cleared the fence came to be called "Chinese". Dan Schlossberg, a veteran [[Associated Press]] baseball writer, accepts the Dorgan story but also reports that [[W. O. McGeehan|Bill McGeehan]], then sports editor of the ''[[New York Tribune]]'', had in 1920 likened the right field fence at the Polo Grounds to the [[Great Wall of China]]: "thick, low, and not very formidable", suggesting that that may also have had something to do with the term's coinage.<ref name="Baseball Bits" /> [[Russ Hodges]], who called Giants games on the radio in both New York and San Francisco, told the latter city's ''[[San Francisco Call|Call-Bulletin]]'' in 1958 that the term came into use from the supposed tendency of Chinese gamblers watching games at the Polo Grounds in the early 20th century to cluster in seats next to the left field foul pole. "Any hit that went out at that point", he explained, "was followed by cries of 'There goes one for the Chinese'".<ref name="Dickson definition" />
Another ''Sporting News'' columnist, [[Joe Falls]], devoted a column to the term and solicited theories of its origin from readers. Some suggested that it had something to do with the "short jump" in [[Chinese checkers]], or that since Chinese people were generally short, that short home runs would be named after them. Another reader claimed that the term arose because the outfield seats in the Polo Grounds supposedly stuck out in ways that suggested a [[pagoda]].<ref name="Dickson definition" />
==History== The term appears to have caught on quickly in baseball throughout the 1920s. By the 1950s, it was still in use but its [[connotation]]s were no longer clear, and its use after one notoriously short home run that won a [[World Series]] game sparked a protest. After the 1964 demolition of the [[Polo Grounds]], with its notoriously short right field fence, the term largely fell from use.<ref name="Dickson definition" />
===1920s–1954: Mel Ott=== [[File:MelOttGoudeycard.jpg|thumb|right|Mel Ott, on a 1933 baseball card]] After establishing itself in baseball's argot, "Chinese home run" continued to be used, even while most of the other derogatory terms related to the Chinese fell from use; the American public opinion began to see the Chinese people in a more sympathetic light due to China's struggles against Japanese domination during the 1930s, struggles that led to the U.S. and China becoming allies during World War II. Within baseball it was frequently associated with the Giants and the Polo Grounds, with its short right-field fence. One Giant in particular, outfielder [[Mel Ott]], was sometimes described as the master of the Chinese home run, since he hit many of his 511 career home runs (a [[National League]] record at the time of his retirement) to right field in the team's home stadium (although often to the upper deck) during his 1926–45 playing career.<ref name="Baseball and the Mythic Moment">{{cite book|last1=Hardy Jr.|first1=James D.|authorlink=James D. Hardy, Jr.|title=Baseball and the Mythic Moment: How We Remember the National Game|date=2007|publisher=McFarland & Company|location=Jefferson, North Carolina|isbn=9780786426508|pages=32–34|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xCE35pZXU0QC&pg=PA33|accessdate=March 13, 2015}}</ref>
The association likely developed because not only did Ott not have the physique commonly associated with [[power hitter]]s, he used an unusual batting technique. The {{convert|5|ft|9|in|cm|adj=on}} outfielder preceded his swings by dropping his hands, lifting his front leg and stepping forward on it as the [[pitch (baseball)|pitch]] came. Since that defied accepted baseball wisdom about how to hit home runs, it was assumed that Ott was focusing on the short right field fence, and sportswriters often kidded him about this. Ott, who worked on his technique extensively, usually responded that if it was so easy, other batters in the league should have been able to hit even more of those home runs when visiting the Giants. It has also been pointed out that Ott's best-known home run, which won his team the [[1933 World Series]] from the [[History of the Washington Senators (1901–60)|Washington Senators]], was hit in [[Griffith Stadium]], not the Polo Grounds, and over a longer fence.<ref name="Baseball and the Mythic Moment" />
===1954–57: Dusty Rhodes=== While [[Bobby Thomson]]'s 1951 pennant-clinching "[[Shot Heard 'Round the World (baseball)|Shot Heard 'Round The World]]" has sometimes been described as a Chinese home run,<ref name="Dickson definition" /> the best-known such hit by a Giant in the Polo Grounds also won an [[extra innings|extra-inning]] [[World Series]] game, and may have proved decisive in eventually winning that series for the Giants. In the 10th inning of Game 1 of the [[1954 World Series]] against the heavily favored [[Cleveland Indians]], Giants' manager [[Leo Durocher]], on a hunch, sent in [[Dusty Rhodes (outfielder)|Dusty Rhodes]] to [[pinch hit]] for [[Monte Irvin]]. The left-handed Rhodes hit a [[walk-off home run]] just over the right field fence, giving the Giants the three runs they needed to win the game.<ref name="Baseball and the Mythic Moment" />
The extensive media coverage led to discussions of both the term, such as Sheehan's in the ''[[New York Times|Times]]'', and Chinese home runs themselves. Since the late 1940s, there had been complaints from older fans that they were part of the decline of the game. "Ballplayers played ball in those days", said a writer in a 1948 column in the [[Lowell, Massachusetts]], ''[[The Sun (Lowell)|Sun]]''. "Now they pop a Chinese home run into an overhanging balcony and the crowd thinks it's wonderful".<ref name="Lighter ADS post 1" /> Two years later, Richard Maney included the Chinese home run among the failings of the postwar game in a ''Times'' piece.<ref name="NYT 1950 Maney piece">{{cite news|last=Maney|first=Richard|title=Shades of Abner Doubleday!; From a grandstand seat on Broadway, this baseball fan rises to denounce the modern game as ersatz, a fraud and a bore.|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1950/09/10/archives/shades-of-abner-doubleday-from-a-grandstand-seat-on-broadway-this.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 10, 1950|accessdate=March 13, 2015|quote=Another victim of the Chinese home run is the [[base stealing|stolen base]].}}</ref>
That 1954 game is chiefly remembered today for [[Willie Mays]]' [[The Catch (baseball)|catch]] of a [[Vic Wertz]] fly to deep center in the eighth inning, which broke up an Indians' rally that might otherwise have led to them winning the game. It had happened because of the {{convert|483|ft|adj=on}} distance of the Polo Grounds' fences in that area, its other peculiarity, which offset the advantage to hitters of its short right-field fence. The Indians attributed their upset loss to the park's unusual dimensions. "The longest out and the shortest home run of the season beat us, that's all", Indians manager [[Al López]] told the ''[[Washington Post]]''. The team was unable to recover psychologically,<ref name="Indians 1954 history">{{cite book|last1=Webster|first1=Gary|title=0.721: A History of the 1954 Cleveland Indians|date=2013|publisher=McFarland & Company|location=Jefferson, North Carolina|isbn=9781476605623|page=158|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rd_-AAAAQBAJ&pg=PA158|accessdate=March 16, 2015}}</ref> and the Giants swept them three games later.<ref name="Blame game">{{cite book|last1=Billheimer|first1=John|title=Baseball and the Blame Game: Scapegoating in the Major Leagues|date=2007|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9780786429066|pages=94–96|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Z1bkbVyrKHMC&pg=PA94|accessdate=March 14, 2015}}</ref>
Sportswriters made much humor of the "Chinese" aspect of Rhodes' home run. One newspaper's photographer posed him reading a Chinese newspaper, apparently looking for an account of his hit.<ref name="Summer of Shadows">{{cite book|last1=Knight|first1=Jonathan|title=Summer of Shadows: A Murder, A Pennant Race, and the Twilight of the Best Location in the Nation|date=2013|publisher=Clerisy Press|isbn=9781578604678|page=110|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R5eLAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA110|accessdate=March 14, 2015}}</ref> The ''New York Times'' called it "more Chinese than [[chow mein]] and just as Chinese as [[Shanghai]] and [[Beijing|Peiping]]".<ref name="NYT 1954 story">{{cite news|last=Daley|first=Arthur|title=Sports of the Times: The Psychic Durocher Clicks|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1954/09/30/archives/sports-of-the-times-the-psychic-durocher-clicks.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=September 30, 1954|accessdate=March 14, 2015}}</ref>
[[Dick Young (sportswriter)|Dick Young]] extended this [[Trope (literature)|trope]] the furthest in his ''[[New York Daily News|Daily News]]'' coverage:<ref name="Bill Madden book" /> {{quote|The story of the Giants' 5–2 win over Cleveland in yesterday's World Series opener should be written vertically, from top to bottom ... in [[Chinese characters|Chinese hieroglyphics]]. It was won on a 10th inning homer that was not only [[sudden death (sport)|sudden death]] but pure murder ... right out of a [[Charlie Chan]] yarn. Ming Toy Rhodes, sometimes called Dusty by his Occidental friends, was honorable person who, as a pinch hitter, delivered miserable bundle of wet wash to first row in rightfield of Polo Grounds, some 259{{frac|1|2}} feet down the road from the [[Chinese laundry|laundry]].}}
This unrestrained use of [[Stereotypes of East Asians in the United States|Chinese stereotypes]], both in content and phrasing, drew a protest. Shavey Lee, long considered the unofficial "mayor" of New York's [[Chinatown, Manhattan|Chinatown]], collected signatures on a [[petition]] (in Chinese<ref name="Mears auction page">{{cite web|title=Lot #641: 1954 "Chinese Home Run" Protest Letter "The Sporting News Collection Archives" Original 8" x 10" Photo (Sporting News Collection Hologram/MEARS Photo LOA) – Lot of 2|url=http://sports.mearsonlineauctions.com/1954-%22chinese-home-run%22-protest-letter-%22the-sporting-news-collection-archives%22-original-8%22-x-10%22-pho-lot43120.aspx|publisher=[[Mears Online Auctions]]|date=April 30, 2011|accessdate=March 19, 2015}}</ref>) from himself and other members of the city's [[Chinese American]] community, demanding not just Young but ''all'' sportswriters stop using the term, and presented it to the Giants' secretary Eddie Brannick.<ref name="Bill Madden book" /> "It isn't the fault of the Chinese if you have a 258-foot fence", he wrote. "Why should we be blamed all the time? What makes a cheesy home run a Chinese home run?"<ref name="Bill Madden book" />
After Brannick posted it on the wall of the team's press room, Lee's petition earned him congratulatory letters from Chinese Americans all over the country, and became national news, earning time on the television series ''[[What's the Story]]''. Jack Orr, a ''[[Sporting News]]'' writer, went to Lee's restaurant and told him he was right to object. "Writers shouldn't be using that term", he said. "But what took you so long to get around to protesting?"<ref name="Bill Madden book" /> Two years later, another New York sportswriter, [[Jimmy Cannon]], noted when defining "Chinese home run" in a glossary of baseball terms he wrote for ''[[Baseball Digest]]'' that it "would probably be called something else if the Chinese had more influence".<ref name="Dickson definition" />
The Giants [[1957 New York Giants (MLB) season#Relocation to San Francisco|moved from the Polo Grounds to San Francisco at the end of the 1957 season]]. Chinese home runs were once again a subject of discussion, with many writers recalling short shots like Thomson's and Rhodes' as a quirk of the former stadium now lost to baseball. Writing in ''The New York Times'' as [[spring training]] was underway, [[Gay Talese]] wrote that Giants' players in their new home missed the "cheap (or Chinese) home runs ... legal nonetheless".<ref name="Talese NYT piece">{{cite news|last=Talese|first=Gay|authorlink=Gay Talese|title=Rigney's Players Yearn for Cabbies, Cheap Homers and Even Ebbets Field|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1958/03/03/archives/rigneys-players-yearn-for-cabbies-cheap-homers-and-even-ebbets.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 3, 1958|accessdate=March 14, 2015}}</ref>
===1958–61: Los Angeles Coliseum=== Another park quickly took over the Polo Grounds' reputation for Chinese home runs. New York City's other National League team, the [[Brooklyn Dodgers]], had also moved to the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] for [[1958 Los Angeles Dodgers season|the 1958 season]], where they played their first home games in the [[Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum]]. Built for the [[1932 Summer Olympic Games|1932 Olympics]], it had mainly been used for [[American football|football]] since then. Its field was well-suited for that sport and the track and field events it had been designed for, but putting a baseball diamond in it was awkward.<ref name="Farewell to the Last Golden Era">{{cite book|last1=Morales|first1=Bill|title=Farewell to the Last Golden Era: The Yankees, the Pirates and the 1960 Baseball Season|date=2011|publisher=McFarland & Company|location=Jefferson, North Carolina|isbn=9780786485680|pages=81–82|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=VZV-gXBxKhYC&pg=PA81|accessdate=March 15, 2015}}</ref> The left field pole was just {{convert|251|ft}} from the plate, even shorter than right had been at the Polo Grounds, and it was much more likely that balls would be hit there due to the majority of batters being right-handed. Before the [[regular season]] even began, players from other teams were complaining about it.<ref name="2008 NYT story">{{cite news|last=Schwarz|first=Alan|authorlink=Alan Schwarz|title=201 Feet to Left, 440 Feet to Right: Dodgers Play the Coliseum|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/26/sports/baseball/26coliseum.html|newspaper=The New York Times|date=March 26, 2008|accessdate=March 14, 2015}}</ref>
Giants' [[pitcher]] [[Johnny Antonelli]] called it a "farce". [[Warren Spahn]], [[Ace (baseball)|ace]] for the [[1957 World Series|defending World Series champion]] [[Milwaukee Braves]], suggested that a rule be established requiring that all fences be at least 300 feet (91 m) from the plate.<ref name="2008 NYT story" /> Owner [[Walter O'Malley]] ordered that a {{convert|40|ft|adj=on}} wire mesh screen be put up behind the left field fence. "We don't want to acquire a reputation for Chinese home runs", he said.<ref name="Bilko Atheltic Club">{{cite book|last1=White|first1=Gaylon H.|title=The Bilko Athletic Club: The Story of the 1956 Los Angeles Angels|date=2014|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9780810892903|page=31|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mEsJAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA3|accessdate=March 15, 2015}}</ref> Sports media, particularly back in New York, charged that O'Malley was destroying the game for the sake of ticket sales. ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' titled a critical [[editorial]] "Every Sixth Hit a Homer!", expressing concern that [[Babe Ruth]]'s record of 60 home runs during a season might easily fall to a less worthy hitter in the coming season due to the Dodgers' short fence.<ref name="Mover and Shaker">{{cite book|last1=McCue|first1=Andy|title=Mover and Shaker: Walter O'Malley, the Dodgers, and Baseball's Westward Expansion|date=2014|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln, Nebraska|isbn=9780803255050|pages=221–22|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vh0KAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA221|accessdate=March 15, 2015}}</ref> An Associated Press (AP) poll of baseball writers found that a majority believed that any home run records set mainly in the Coliseum should carry an [[Asterisk#Baseball|asterisk]].<ref name="Farewell to the Last Golden Era" />
As had happened with Rhodes' home run four years earlier, the Chinese-themed joking around the short fence continued. The screen was called the "Chinese screen" or the "[[Great Wall of China]]",<ref name="Farewell to the Last Golden Era" /> and the Coliseum as a whole became known as "O'Malley's Chinese Theatre",<ref name="Mover and Shaker" /> "The House that Charlie Chan Built",<ref name="Close Shave">{{cite book|last1=Szalontai|first1=James D.|title=Close Shave: The Life and Times of Baseball's Sal Maglie|date=2002|publisher=McFarland & Company|location=Jefferson, North Carolina|isbn=9780786411894|page=356|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sxQ0aNbCw-kC&pg=PA356|accessdate=March 15, 2015}}</ref> or even, in one [[Willard Mullin]] cartoon, "Flung Wong O'Malley's Little Joss House in Los Angeles".<ref name="Dickson definition" /> ''The Sporting News'', contrary to the preseason trend, editorialized that it could not yet be said that the short wall would adversely affect the game. But on the cover of that issue (which also included Spink's [[etymology|etymological]] investigation) it put a cartoon showing an outsized Chinese [[coolie]] hanging over the Coliseum's back fence.<ref name="The Empire Strikes Out">{{cite book|last1=Elias|first1=Robert|title=The Empire Strikes Out: How Baseball Sold U.S. Foreign Policy and Promoted the American Way Abroad|date=2010|publisher=[[The New Press]]|isbn=9781595585288|page=1961|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o1YkeL_97hIC&pg=RA1-PA1961|accessdate=March 15, 2015}}</ref>{{efn|The cover design, with its suggestions of the [[Yellow Peril]], may also have reflected another change in American perceptions of the Chinese. Nine years earlier, the [[Communist Party of China|Communists]] had won [[Chinese Civil War|China's civil war]] and established the [[China|People's Republic of China]], ostensibly allied with the Soviet Union against the U.S. in the [[Cold War]]. At that time, with China undergoing its [[Great Leap Forward]], an attempt to rapidly industrialize the country, Americans were particularly fearful of what Chinese workers might be able to accomplish.<ref name="Close Shave" />}} The Chinese American community in the Los Angeles area made its objections known.<ref name="Close Shave" />
At first the worst fears of the media appeared justified. In the first week of play at the Coliseum, 24 home runs were hit, most of them over the left field fence and screen. [[Chicago Cubs]] outfielder [[Lee Walls]], not especially distinguished as a hitter, was responsible for three of them—in a single game. [[Commissioner of Baseball|Baseball Commissioner]] [[Ford Frick]], who had defended the Coliseum's dimensions during the preseason, quickly proposed that a second, {{convert|60|ft|adj=on}} mesh screen be established in the stands at {{convert|333|ft}} from the plate, with any balls that fell between the two a [[ground rule double]]; however, that turned to be impossible under earthquake-safety provisions of the Los Angeles building code.<ref name="2008 NYT story" />
Pitchers soon adjusted. They threw outside to right-handed hitters, requiring them to [[Pull hitter|pull]] hard for the left-field fence, and as at the Polo Grounds, a deep fence in right center ({{convert|444|ft}}) challenged lefties, and over the course of the season the home run count at the Coliseum declined to the same level as other National League parks. At the end of the season, ''The Sporting News'' noted, there had been only 21 more home runs in the Coliseum than there were in the smaller [[Ebbets Field]], where the Dodgers had played in [[Brooklyn]].<ref name="2008 NYT story" /> During the off-season, Frick announced a rule change stipulating that any new stadium built for major-league play must have all its fences at least {{convert|325|ft}} from home plate, as Spahn had suggested. This was widely viewed as a response to the preseason controversy.<ref name="Home Run">{{cite book|last1=Vincent|first1=David|title=Home Run: The Definitive History of Baseball's Ultimate Weapon|date=2011|publisher=Potomac Books|location=Washington, D.C.|isbn=9781597976572|page=104|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_69wBas7CsoC&pg=PA104|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref>
The only hitter to truly benefit from the short left-field fence was [[Wally Moon]], a left-handed outfielder who began playing for the Dodgers [[1959 Los Angeles Dodgers season|the next season]]. He figured out how to lift balls high enough so that they dropped down, almost vertically, just beyond the screen. This brought him 37 of his 49 homers for that season. He was not accused of exploiting the short distance to the fence for Chinese home runs. Instead, he was celebrated for his inventiveness; similar home runs have since been called "[[Moonshot (baseball)|Moon shots]]" in his honor.<ref name="2008 NYT story" /> [[File:LA Coliseum 1959 World Series.jpg|thumb|left|Short left field line in Los Angeles Coliseum, seen here during the 1959 World Series|alt=A baseball game being played in a stadium with high stands, seen from the right field side. The United States and Los Angeles flags are flying above the left field foul line, which is shorter than usual]] Game 5 of [[1959 World Series|that year's World Series]], ultimately won by the Dodgers over the [[Chicago White Sox]], would be the last postseason [[Major League Baseball]] game played at the Coliseum. After two more seasons at the Coliseum, the Dodgers moved to [[Dodger Stadium]] in 1962, where they have played home games since. After the then–[[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim|Los Angeles Angels']] first [[American League]] season in 1961, the club asked for a new home in the Los Angeles area, initially asking if they could play in the Coliseum. Frick refused.<ref name="Purdy team encyclopedia">{{cite book|last1=Purdy|first1=Dennis|title=The Team by Team Encyclopedia of Major League Baseball|date=2006|publisher=[[Workman Publishing]]|isbn=9780761139430|page=510|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uXCw8nHLVRQC&pg=PA510|accessdate=March 18, 2015}}</ref>
In 2008, to celebrate their 50th anniversary in Los Angeles, the Dodgers played a preseason [[exhibition game]] at the Coliseum against the [[Boston Red Sox]], losing by a score of 7–1. The wire mesh screen was restored, this time at the {{convert|60|ft|adj=on}} height Frick had sought because an additional section of seats had been added there since 1959, shortening left field to {{convert|201|ft}}. A Dodgers executive noted that it mimicked the [[Green Monster]] in left field at [[Fenway Park]], the Red Sox' home field.<ref name="2008 NYT story" />
===1962–63: Return of the Polo Grounds=== In 1962, baseball returned to the Polo Grounds when the National League created the [[New York Mets]] as an [[expansion team]], to replace the Giants and Dodgers. The new team used the old stadium for two seasons while [[Shea Stadium]] was built out in the [[Queens]] neighborhood of [[Flushing, Queens|Flushing]]. The Mets lost the franchise's first six games at the Giants' former home, on their way to [[1962 New York Mets season|a 40–120 record]], still the most losses in a major-league season, but in those games they and their opponents hit ten home runs apiece. Sportswriters took notice, and one AP writer picked up where Dick Young had left off eight years before: "So solly, honorable sir. Chinese home run not buried in Coliseum. Making big comeback in honorable ancient Polo Grounds".<ref name="April 1962 AP story">{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Chinese Home Run Making Big Comeback at Polo Grounds|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2199&dat=19620421&id=WT0yAAAAIBAJ&sjid=O-UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=7241,1619877|newspaper=[[Lawrence Journal-World]]|location=Lawrence, Massachusetts|date=April 21, 1962|accessdate=March 16, 2015}}</ref>
While the team's poor play and last-place finishes in its two seasons in the Polo Grounds left few individual home runs over the right-field fence to become the subject of popular comment and mockery as Rhodes' had, the term was still in use during the team's radio broadcasts, as Yale professor Dana Brand recalled in his 2007 memoir, ''Mets Fan'': {{quote|If you hit a 300-foot home run in the Polo Grounds, [[Lindsey Nelson]] or [[Ralph Kiner]] or [[Bob Murphy (announcer)|Bob Murphy]] would call it a Chinese home run. Obviously, they wouldn't call it a Chinese home run now, even if you could still hit a 300-foot home run. To this day, I don't know what made a home run like this Chinese. Was it because it was short, something a small person could hit? Was there some implication that it was tricky or cheap or sneaky? What a strange world that was.<ref name="Mets Fan">{{cite book|last1=Brand|first1=Dana|title=Mets Fan|date=2007|publisher=McFarland & Company|location=Jefferson, North Carolina|isbn=9780786482481|page=18|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fkaPAhnpQnQC&pg=PA18|accessdate=March 16, 2015}}</ref>}}
Problems in completing Shea Stadium forced the Mets to stay [[1963 New York Mets season|one season more]]. At one point during the season, manager [[Casey Stengel]] alluded to the short home runs when berating pitcher [[Tracy Stallard]]. "At the end of this season they're gonna tear this place down", he reminded Stallard as he took him out of a game in which he had given up several home runs. "The way you're pitching, that right field section is gone already". In April 1964, the Polo Grounds were demolished and replaced with [[Polo Grounds Towers|a public housing project]].<ref name="American Places">{{cite book|last1=Leuchtenberg|first1=William E.|title=American Places: Encounters with History|date=2002|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195152456|page=308|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kyq6JlqU58kC&pg=PA308|accessdate=March 16, 2015}}</ref>
===1965–present: Disuse=== Use of the term largely faded out afterwards, and it was seen as offensive. In 1981 ''San Francisco Chronicle'' columnist [[Herb Caen]] criticized [[Oakland Athletics|Oakland A's]] radio announcer [[Bill King]] for saying a [[Bobby Murcer]] shot was "not a Chinese home run". Caen called the remark "racist" and wrote: "I'm sure he has heard from militant Oriental groups, all of which hit hard".<ref name="Dickson definition" />
==Secondary definition== Dickson found another usage, referring to a high [[foul ball]] that travels a great distance, usually behind home plate. In [[Stephen King]]'s 1980 short story "[[The Monkey]]", anthologized five years later in ''[[Skeleton Crew]]'', the protagonists' father recalls days watching [[sandlot baseball|sandlot]] games during his own childhood, when he "was too small to play, but he sat far out in foul territory sucking his blueberry [[Ice pop|Pop]]sicle and chasing what the big kids called 'Chinese home runs'". Dickson wrote to King, who told him two years later that he had first heard the term when learning to play baseball in his own childhood, during a time when he lived, briefly, in [[Stratford, Connecticut]]. After he returned to his native [[Maine]] in 1958, the same year the Giants and Dodgers moved west, he recalled hearing it again. "In both cases", he told Dickson, "a Chinese home run was a foul ball, usually over the backstop". Dickson concluded from his correspondence that that use may well be limited to [[New England]].<ref name="Dickson definition" /> All three definitions submitted to the online [[Urban Dictionary]] in the early 21st century are in accord with this usage.<ref name="Urban Dictionary">{{cite web|title=Chinese home run|url=http://www.urbandictionary.com/define.php?term=Chinese+homerun|publisher=[[Urban Dictionary]]|date=2006–2011|accessdate=March 17, 2015}}</ref>
According to Dickson, one of the etymologies submitted to Joe Falls' ''Sporting News'' column, by a [[St. Louis]] man named Tom Becket, may explain this usage. "In this version, the term harks back to the turn of the 20th century and a game played in [[Salem, Massachusetts]], between teams of [[Irish Americans|Irish]] and [[Polish American|Polish immigrants]]". The game was close, and went deep into [[extra innings]]. By the 17th inning, only one ball was left. A [[shortstop]] named [[Chaney]], playing for the Irish team, fouled the ball deep into unmowed grass and weeds behind the [[backstop (baseball)|backstop]]. After searching through it for 20 minutes, the [[Umpire (baseball)|umpire]] gave up and declared that the Polish team had [[Forfeit (baseball)|forfeited]] the game since it had failed to provide enough balls. "So the cheer went up, 'Chaney's home run won the game!'", Becket explained. "[[Corruption (linguistics)|Various misunderstandings as to dialects]] eventually brought it around to the now-familiar 'Chinese home run'".<ref name="Dickson definition" />
==See also== {{portal|Asian Americans|Baseball|Linguistics}} *[[Sport in China#Baseball|Baseball in China]] *[[Chinese fire drill]], another derogatory term from the early 20th century that has survived that era *[[Glossary of baseball]] *[[Left-arm unorthodox spin]], a [[cricket]] [[bowling (cricket)|bowling]] technique sometimes referred to as a Chinaman, supposedly after an early player to use it
==Notes== {{Notelist}}

[[Image:Château de Beaucens - Ruines - Desrosiers -1836 - L'art en province.JPG|right|thumb|350px|Château de Beaucens, 1836]] The '''Château de Beaucens''', is a 14th-century ruined [[castle]] in the ''[[Communes of France|commune]]'' of [[Beaucens ]] in the [[Hautes-Pyrénées]] ''[[Departments of France|département]]'' of France.<ref name=MinCult>Ministry of Culture: [http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/merimee_fr?ACTION=RETROUVER&REQ=((PA00095344):REF) Restes du château]. Retrieved 29 November 2018. {{fr}}</ref> The site has been transformed into a [[zoological park]], the "''Donjon des Aigles''" (eagles' keep), where one may admire [[Bird of prey|birds of prey]] in flight around the ruins of the castle, with a view over the [[Lavedan|vallée des Gaves]].
== History == [[File:Château de Beaucens - Plan - 1866 - M de Caumont -.JPG|thumb|right|150px|Plan of Château de Beaucens in 1866]] [[File:Château de Beaucens - Vues - 1866 - M de Caumont -.JPG|thumb|right|150px|Views of Château de Beaucens in 1866]] Construction of the castle began in 1037. Altered and expanded several times, <ref name=CdeB>[http://www.beaucens.fr/histoire-patrimoine/patrimoine-architectural/55-le-chateau-de-beaucens "Le château de Beaucens"], Commune de Beaucens web site {{fr icon}} Retrieved 29 November 2018. {{fr icon}}</ref> it was the property of the Viscounts of Castet-Loubon<ref>{{cite book|language=fr|first=Thomas|last= Corneille|authorlink1= Thomas Corneille|title=Dictionnaire universel, géographique et historique. Contenant la description des royaumes, empires, estats,... ; La situation, l'estendue, les limites, les distances de chaque pays ; La religion, les mœurs, les coustumes, le commerce ; Les cérémonies, particulières des peuples|publisher=Jean Baptiste Coignardlieu |date=1708|volume=|isbn=|url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=hOt9zDlk9bEC&hl=fr&hl=fr&pg=PA459&img=1&zoom=3&sig=ACfU3U2HqpWnxlZtgekjOa37IOokB1F77g&ci=451%2C583%2C407%2C291&edge=0|accessdate=29 November 2018}}</ref> commonly known as the Viscounts of [[Lavedan]]. It was the normal residence of the [[viscountcy]], the most powerful in [[Bigorre]] with vast possessions including seventeen towns in the [[Barèges]] valley,<ref>{{cite book|language=fr|first= Armand|last=Davezac-Macaya|authorlink= |title=Essais historiques sur le Bigorre|publisher=A. Davezac-Macaya |date=1823 |volume=2 |isbn= |url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=gz5a-kxZBNQC&pg=PA37&dq=%22+ch%C3%A2teau+de+Beaucens%22&hl=fr&sa=X&ei=Dv2iUYD-II26hAethYGwBA&ved=0CEsQ6AEwBDg8#v=onepage&q=%22%20ch%C3%A2teau%20de%20Beaucens%22&f=false|accessdate=29 November 2018}}</ref> They owned it for several centuries, but from the 15th century, they rarely stayed there, using it only when conducting business in the area.
In 1560, in events leading up to the [[French Wars of Religion]], the Viscount, as a [[Huguenot]], saw his castle pillaged by Catholic forces.<ref>A and F Meillon, [https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k65358291/f433.image.r=%22Ch%C3%A2teau%20de%20Beaucens%22?rk=386268;0 "L'abbaye de Saint-Savin en Lavedan jusgu'a la Revolution"], ''Bulletin de la Société académique des Hautes-Pyrénées'', 1936, pages 767, 800. {{fr icon}} Retrieved 29 November 2018.</ref>
The castle was inhabited in 1643, when it belonged then to [[:fr:Philippe de Montaut-Bénac de Navailles|the house of Montaut-Bénac]]<ref>{{cite book|language=fr|first=Justin-Édouard|last=Cénac-Moncaut|title=Voyage archéologique et historique dans l'ancien comté de Bigorre|publisher= |location=|date=1856|volume= |url=http://books.google.fr/books?id=ORdZR-P0u8IC&hl=fr&hl=fr&pg=PA98&img=1&zoom=3&sig=ACfU3U2ahNDmy3Cm52742_hziWSRhgROpw&ci=146%2C618%2C787%2C158&edge=0|accessdate=29 November 2018}} Justin-Édouard M. Cénac-Moncaut mentions the [[earthquake]] of July 1854 which so strongly shook the base of the square tower in the southwestern corner that it inevitably collapsed. Only the [[keep]] was built strong enough.</ref>
[[Françoise Bertaut de Motteville|Madame de Motteville]] stayed at the castle for the wedding of [[Louis XIV of France|Louis XIV]]<ref>Victor Adolphe Malte-Brun, ''[https://books.google.fr/books?id=-MhBAAAAcAAJ&pg=PR167&dq=%22+ch%C3%A2teau+de+Beaucens%22&hl=fr&sa=X&ei=tlyjUd_9NIfF7AallYHoCg&ved=0CGkQ6AEwCTgU#v=onepage&q=%22%20ch%C3%A2teau%20de%20Beaucens%22&f=false La France illustrée: Géographie, histoire, administration et statistique]'' Volume 2 {{fr icon}}</ref> and [[Maria Theresa of Spain]], on 9 June 1660 at the [[:fr:Église Saint-Jean-Baptiste (Saint-Jean-de-Luz)|church of Saint John the Baptiste]] in [[Saint-Jean-de-Luz]]. She compared it to the palace of the fairy Urgande.<ref>[https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6535686c/f30.image.r=%22Ch%C3%A2teau%20de%20Beaucens%22 "Livre Vert de Bénac"], ''Bulletin documentaire'' (Société académique des Hautes-Pyrénées), 1910, page 22. {{fr icon}} Retrieved 29 November 2018.</ref>
Prince [[Charles Louis Gaspard de Rohan-Rochefort]], the 31st and last viscount, who lived there, had married his cousin, Marie Louise Joséphine de Rohan.<ref>Henri de Curzon [https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5090629/f4.image.r=%22Charles%20Louis%20Gaspard%20de%20Rohan-Rochefort%22?rk=150215;2 "Une fête de nuit à Paris à la fin du XVIIIe siecle"], ''Journal des Débats Politiques et Litteraires'', No. 65, 18 March 1938, page 4. {{fr icon}} Retrieved 29 November 2018.</ref> He was extremely unpopular with the population of Bigorre.<ref>L Ricaud, ''La Bigorre et les Haute-Pyrénées pendant la Révolution'', reviewed in [https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5725855h/f224.image.r=%22Prince%20de%20Rohan-Rochefort,%22 "Publications historiques sur la Region Pyrénéene"] ''Revue de Gascoigne'', vol '''XXXVI''', January 1895 pages 216-7 {{fr icon}} Retrieved 29 November 2018.</ref>In 1792, during the [[French Revolution]], he fled to Austria leaving behind his wife - she asked for and received a divorce - and his papers. When the castle was set on fire, they were lost. The Princess managed to keep some of the property, including the castle: in 1802 she sold all of the possessions in Bigorre. The castle then belonged to a succession of owners.<ref name=CdeB/>
An earthquake in 1854 caused part of the ''[[enceinte]]'' to collapse.<ref>Eugene Duviau, [https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k9790176g/f36.image.r=%22Ch%C3%A2teau%20de%20Beaucens%22?rk=1051507;2 "Tremblements de terre et autre phenomenes extraordinaires remargues a Lourdes et ses environs"], ''En cournè det houéc'', winter 1938-39, page 124. {{fr icon}} Retrieved 29 November 2018.</ref> In 1856, the castle became the property of [[Achille Fould|Achille Marcus Fould]] (1800 - 1867), the famous banker and politician. He was [[List of Finance Ministers of France|Minister of Finance]] during the [[French Second Republic|Second Republic]] under [[Napoleon III]] and [[Minister of State]] from 1852 to 1860 during the [[Second French Empire|Second Empire]] of Napoleon III.<ref>{{cite book|language=fr|first=Edmond|last=du Sommerard|title=Catalogue et description des objets d'art, de l'antiquité, du moyen âge et de la renaissance|publisher=|location=Hôtel de Cluny|date= 1862|volume= |url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=Fw5HAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA402&dq=%22+ch%C3%A2teau+de+Beaucens%22&hl=fr&sa=X&ei=tlyjUd_9NIfF7AallYHoCg&ved=0CEMQ6AEwAzgU#v=onepage&q=%22%20ch%C3%A2teau%20de%20Beaucens%22&f=false|accessdate= 29 November 2018}}</ref> The castle was restored by Fould<ref>Anthyme Saint-Paul, [https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k31051q/f752.image.r=%22Ch%C3%A2teau%20de%20Beaucens%22?rk=1158804;0 "Une Excursion Archéologique dans le Bigorre"], ''Bulletin monumental'', Société française pour la conservation et la description des monuments historiques, 1866, see pages 739-747. This article provides a detailed architectural assessment of the castle and its history. {{fr icon}} Retrieved 29 November 2018.</ref> but remained a ruin overgrown by vegetation.<ref name=CdeB/>
It was inscribed on the list of ''[[monument historique|monuments historiques]]'' in 1927.<ref name=MinCult/>
== Legend of the eagle and the trout == In the Bigorre region, legend tells of a long siege of the castle by [[Charlemagne]] which ended because an [[eagle]] with a [[trout]] in its beak led the besiegers to believe that the castle had abundant fresh food.<ref>{{cite journal | language= fr | journal= Revue d'Aquitaine et du Languedoc|title=La Bastide de Rabastens, en Bigorre|author= A Curie-Seimbres|pages=109-119| date = 1864 | volume = 8 | isbn = | url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=dDlNAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA119&dq=aigle+truite+lourdes+chateau&hl=fr&sa=X&ei=MJGjUaX3IYiJhQfmloCwBA&sqi=2&ved=0CEAQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=aigle%20truite%20lourdes%20chateau&f=false | accessdate=29 November 2018}}</ref>
== Geology == At the foot of the castle is a cold sulfurous spring which was drunk by the inhabitants of Beaucens and a lead mine in the rock on which the castle stands.<ref>{{cite book|language=fr|first=A.J.|last=A.J. Killian|title=Dictionnaire géographique universel, contenant la description de tous les lieux du globe intéressants sous le rapport de la géographie physique et politique, de l'histoire, de la statistique, du commerce, de l'industrie|volume=2|passage= |date= |isbn=|url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=4Oc6AAAAcAAJ&hl=fr&hl=fr&pg=PA3&img=1&zoom=3&sig=ACfU3U39pEMrNE6YX7blEVMlVeRIERDLgA&ci=61%2C331%2C428%2C219&edge=0|accessdate=29 November 2018}}</ref>
== Donjon des aigles == Since 1973, the castle has housed one of the world's most important collections of [[Bird of prey|birds of prey]]: : [[kite]]s, [[vulture]], [[eagle]]s, [[sea eagle]]s, [[falcon]]s and [[buzzard]]s. Displays are given featuring an [[Egyptian vulture]], who breaks an imitation ostrich egg with a stone, as well as a [[Andean condor|condor]], various [[owl]]s, [[parakeet]]s and [[parrot]]s.
<gallery> File:Château de Beaucens - Décor-002.JPG|View of the castle File:Château de Beaucens - Décor.JPG File:Château de Beaucens - Donjon des aigles 2013.JPG|Donjon des Aigles in 2013 File:Château de Beaucens - Décor-006.JPG File:Château de Beaucens - Décor-014.JPG File:Château de Beaucens - Décor-022.JPG </gallery>

{{use dmy dates|date=August 2015}} {{infobox country at games | NOC = COL | NOCname = [[Colombian Olympic Committee]] | games = Summer Olympics | year = 1964 | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = {{url|www.coc.org.co }} {{es icon}} | location = [[Tokyo]] | competitors = 20 | sports = 6 | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = | winterappearances = | seealso = }}
'''[[Colombia]]''' competed at the '''[[1964 Summer Olympics]]''' in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]]. 20 competitors, all men, took part in 19 events in 6 sports.<ref name="sports-reference">{{cite web |url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/countries/COL/summer/1964/ |title=Colombia at the 1964 Tokyo Summer Games |accessdate=14 August 2014 |work=sports-reference.com}}</ref>
==Athletics== {{main|Athletics at the 1964 Summer Olympics}}
==Cycling== {{main|Cycling at the 1964 Summer Olympics}} Eight cyclists represented Colombia in 1964.
;[[Cycling at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's individual road race|Individual road race]] * [[Martín Rodríguez (cyclist)|Martín Rodríguez]] * [[Pablo Hernández (cyclist)|Pablo Hernández]] * [[Rubén Darío Gómez]] * [[Mario Escobar]]
;[[Cycling at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's team time trial|Team time trial]] * [[Rubén Darío Gómez]] * [[Pablo Hernández (cyclist)|Pablo Hernández]] * [[Javier Suárez (cyclist)|Javier Suárez]] * [[Pedro Sánchez (cyclist)|Pedro Sánchez]]
;[[Cycling at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's sprint|Sprint]] * [[Mario Vanegas]] * [[Eduardo Bustos]]
;[[Cycling at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's 1000m time trial|1000m time trial]] * [[Eduardo Bustos]]
;[[Cycling at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's individual pursuit|Individual pursuit]] * [[Martín Rodríguez (cyclist)|Martín Rodríguez]]
==Diving== {{main|Diving at the 1964 Summer Olympics}}
==Fencing== {{main|Fencing at the 1964 Summer Olympics}} Five fencers, all men, represented Colombia in 1964.
;[[Fencing at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's foil|Men's foil]] * [[Ignacio Posada]] * [[Emilio Echeverry]] * [[Dibier Tamayo]]
;[[Fencing at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's team foil|Men's team foil]] * [[Ignacio Posada]], [[Dibier Tamayo]], [[Emilio Echeverry]], [[Ernesto Sastre]], [[Humberto Posada]]
;[[Fencing at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's épée|Men's épée]] * [[Dibier Tamayo]] * [[Ernesto Sastre]] * [[Emilio Echeverry]]
;[[Fencing at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's team épée|Men's team épée]] * [[Emilio Echeverry]], [[Ernesto Sastre]], [[Dibier Tamayo]], [[Humberto Posada]]
;[[Fencing at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's sabre|Men's sabre]] * [[Ignacio Posada]] * [[Emilio Echeverry]] * [[Humberto Posada]]
==Shooting== {{main|Shooting at the 1964 Summer Olympics}} One shooter represented Colombia in 1964.
;[[Shooting at the 1964 Summer Olympics – Men's 25 metre rapid fire pistol|25 m pistol]] * [[Antonio Clopatofsky]]
==Swimming== {{main|Swimming at the 1964 Summer Olympics}}
==See also== *[[Sports in Colombia]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{infobox stadium | fullname = Estadio Roberto Martínez Ávila | image = | caption = | former_names = | location = [[Siguatepeque]], [[Honduras]] | coordinates = {{coord|14.59008|-87.841342}} | built = 1980 | opened = 1980 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | owner = [[Siguatepeque|Siguatepeque Municipality]] | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 7,000 | Suites = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Atlético Independiente]] (1980–''present'')
[[Parrillas One]] (2014–2015) }} '''Estadio Roberto Martínez Ávila''' is a [[football (soccer)|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Siguatepeque]], [[Honduras]]. It is currently used mostly for football matches and is the home stadium of [[Atlético Independiente]]. The stadium holds 7,000 people.[http://www.diez.hn/ligadeascenso/933130-99/as%C3%AD-luce-el-estadio-roberto-mart%C3%ADnez-%C3%A1vila-de-siguatepeque-a-36-a%C3%B1os Diez.hn – Así luce el estadio Roberto Martínez Ávila de Siguatepeque a 36 años de su creación] – 24 February 2016 ==Events== The '''Estadio Roberto Martínez Ávila''' hosted the following major international football events. {| class="wikitable" |- ! Competition !! Years |- | [[UNCAF U-19 Tournament]] || [[2018 UNCAF U-19 Tournament|2018]] |} ==External links== *[http://www.siguaonline.com/centrosdeportivos.htm History of the stadium] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Honduran Liga Nacional stadiums}} {{Football in Honduras}} {{coord|14.590080|-87.841342|type:landmark|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Estadio Roberto Martinez Avila}} [[Category:Football venues in Honduras|Roberto Martinez Avila]] {{Honduras-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Orphan|date=February 2009}} [[File:ETDS Groningen-2009-05-30.JPG|thumb|300px|The 41st ETDS in Groningen]] The '''European Tournament for Dancing Students''' or '''ETDS''' is a recurring tournament for [[Ballroom dance|ballroom]] and [[Latin dance|Latin-American]] dancing for students from Europe.
== Introduction == The tournament is held twice a year, once during the [[Pentecost]] weekend and once in autumn. The event always starts on a Friday evening and ends on the following Monday morning. Although each ETDS is organised by a different party, the structure remains fairly constant: on Friday evening, the [[wiktionary:blind date|blind date]] program takes place, in which dancers without a partner can try to find someone with which to compete in one or both dance disciplines. Blind dating is also a motivation for some dancers that want to meet new people. On Saturday, the [[Ballroom dance|ballroom]] tournament for the ''breitensport'' class (German, meaning amateur sports for the masses) takes place and the [[Latin dance|Latin-American]] tournament for the open class as well as, if so chosen by the organising party, for the CloseD class. On Sunday, all classes dance the respective other discipline. The event ends on Monday with a last common breakfast.
The organisation of each tournament is in the hands of a different participating university. The tournament takes place in the city of the organising university, the location changing every half year to another European city. So far, the tournament has taken place most of the times either in [[Germany]] or the [[Netherlands]]. In autumn 2015, the ETDS took place in [[Czech Republic]], breaking that series for the first time. With the participation of some students from South Africa, it also premiered hosting dancers from outside Europe.
Although the primary focus of the ETDS lies in organising a tournament of high standards, the event equally aims at creating a social happening where dancers from all of Europe can meet each other. This is encouraged by the possibility to blind date and by a themed festival ("motto party") on the event's Saturday evening and a gala ball on Sunday evening.
The sleeping accommodation is commonly a local gym.
== History == The ETDS was founded by the university dance teams of [[Clausthal-Zellerfeld|Clausthal]], [[Braunschweig]] and [[Kiel]], who agreed to get to know each other during a tournament. The event was organised by these three German universities for a number of times. There was not a regular structure, but the tournament was organised ad hoc. Finding a sleeping accommodation was easy, as the number of participants was still very low.
In November 1990, a tournament price was introduced that has been used ever since, “der tanzmaus” (German for “the dance mouse”), a pluche mouse. The tanzmaus was a donation of the university of Kiel; Clausthal was the first university to win the mouse. It is given to the winning university which "hosts" the price until the next ETDS.
In December 1991, a tournament during [[Sinterklaas]] took place. The tournament gained more participants and Berlin started participating as well. Berlin won the dance mouse during this Sinterklaas tournament, and promised to organise the event somewhere in the future. During this tournament, only one class existed.
In April 1992, the tournament took place in Clausthal. This was the first tournament in which the team of [[Dortmund]] started participating. Some tournaments later, [[Ulm]] and [[Marburg]] started participating as well.
The University of Berlin fulfilled their promise in 1993 by taking care of the organisation of the tournament. The tournament still did not have separate classes.
The next tournament took place in the spring of 1994, and the tournament gained in popularity; fifteen universities from Germany participated. Also, for the first time, universities from the Netherlands started to participate. The new universities were from [[University of Mainz|Mainz]], [[Geisenheim Grape Breeding Institute|Geisenheim]], [[Kaiserslautern]], [[Delft]] and [[Eindhoven]].
During autumn of 1994, the number of participants had increased to such a high amount that problems started to arise between the organisation and the administration of Kiel. The result was that Kiel was disallowed to organise the event for five years.
The next tournament took place in the spring of 1995, and for the first time, the tournament was separated into two classes. They were called “amateurs” and “profis” ("professionals"). [[Leipzig]] also joined this tournament.
The tournament that was held in the summer of 1995 was the first event to take place in the Netherlands. The organisation was in the hands of [[ESDV Footloose]] from [[Eindhoven]]. [[Groningen (city)|Groningen]] joined during this tournament. From now on, the ETDS was no longer organised on an ad hoc basis, but was organised regularly twice each year, during Pentecost and in the autumn, each time by a different university.
The number of participants continued to grow, and around 2004 a third class, "masters", was added to the breitensport section. More than 500 participants took part in the 41st tournament in Groningen in May 2009, and another breitensport class by the name of “champions” was introduced.
The event continued to grow in popularity, and 570 participants were competing in the 47th edition during Pentecost, May 2012. In October 2015, the event was held for the first time in the Czech Republic, in the city of [[Brno]]. This was the first ETDS not organised in Germany or the Netherlands.
== Rules == Every ETDS organisation is allowed to make their own rules for the tournament. Each organisation describes rules about clothing and the calculation of the tanzmaus evaluation. Because the focus of each organization may be different, the balance between social orientation and competition changes slightly. Nevertheless, several rules exist during each tournament:
=== Structure === Dancers can sign up for two disciplines, [[Ballroom dance|standard]] and [[Latin dance|Latin-American]].
In the breitensport class, only untrained and low level training dancers are allowed. Professional dancers, i.e. those who have reached a higher class in official tournaments held by dance associations, are excluded from the breitensport tournaments. They instead dance in the open class which ranges at least from B to S class dancers.
Some hosting universities decide to provide another separate tournament for a class called CloseD, which consists of dancers of the official D and C classes (varying between national dance associations). In case a separate tournament for this class is chosen not to be held, the organising team will classify the concerning dancers into either breitensport (D class) or open class (C class).
Participants that belong to a [[Formation dance|dance formation]] may also be required to dance in the CloseD or open class, depending on the league in which their formation is classified.
In the breitensport section, a pre-qualification round takes place, where each participating couple is classified into the amateur, professional ("profi"), master or the optional champion class, so that each couple will dance the subsequent actual tournament in a class that matches their levels. These tournaments follow the rules of official dancing tournaments. During the finals, open adjudication is sometimes performed, with each adjudicator showing their ranking of the couples on the floor immediately after each dance. However, closed adjudication is often chosen in order to save time. There are winner's certificates and medals for all participants in the finals as well as trophies (instead of medals) for the [[podium]] finishers.
=== Dances=== In the respective disciplines, the following dances have to be performed (example rule set): * ''Breitensport'': ballroom preliminary round: [[Waltz (International Standard)|slow waltz]], [[Tango (ballroom)|tango]], [[quickstep]], from the semi-final of masters and champions additionally: [[Viennese waltz]] and/or [[slowfox]]; latin preliminary round: [[Cha-cha-cha (dance)|cha-cha-cha]], [[Rhumba|rumba]], [[Jive (dance)|jive]], from the semi-final of masters and champions additionally: [[Samba (ballroom dance)|samba]], [[paso doble]] * ''CloseD'': similar to breitensport, but with a re-dance round for those who didn't directly qualify for the next round * ''Open class'': similar to CloseD The ETDS has also seen separate competitions without class separation in [[Discofox]], [[Salsa (dance)|Salsa]] and [[Polka]].
=== Adjudication === The adjudicators are chosen from volunteers of the participating universities that do not compete themselves in the discipline in which they judge. Adjudicators are selected by their adjudicator's license, by their experience and/or by their level of dancing in regular dance competitions.
=== Blind dating === A blind date couple consists of two dancers from different universities. Blind dating is mandatory in the CloseD and open classes (in the latter case sometimes being replaced by composing couples by the lot or by other rules), and stimulated in the breitensport by a blind date programme on Friday and Saturday for the following day's tournament. During the breitensport tournaments, a blind date couple can score more points for a university, and thereby improve their team's chance of winning the tanzmaus prize.
=== Participants === Every member of a student dancing society or university student can participate. Each couple dances under the flag of his or her university or dance society. Staff members of the university or dancing society are also allowed to participate. When universities have too few participants to compete for the tanzmaus, they can team up with other universities to improve their chances.
== Nationalities == Every European university or student dance society can participate. In practice, a majority of the participants is German. The second largest participating party is from the Netherlands, and some dancers from the [[United Kingdom]], [[Switzerland]], [[Estonia]], [[Norway]] and other neighbouring countries participate as well.
=== Germany === From Germany, universities from the following cities have been participating in the ETDS: * [[Aachen]] * [[Berlin]] * [[Bielefeld]] * [[Bonn]] * [[Braunschweig]] * [[Clausthal]] * [[Cottbus]] * [[Darmstadt]] * [[Dortmund]] * [[Düsseldorf]] * [[Erlangen]] * [[Frankfurt]] * [[Geisenheim]] * [[Gießen]] * [[Göttingen]] * [[Hannover]] * [[Hildesheim]] * [[Kaiserslautern]] * [[Karlsruhe]] * [[Kehl]] * [[Kiel]] * [[Leipzig]] * [[Mainz]] * [[Marburg]] * [[München]] * [[Münster]] * [[Stuttgart]] * [[Ulm]]
=== The Netherlands === In the Netherlands, the participants often dance under the flag of a dancing society, unlike in Germany, where participants dance under the flag of their university. From the Netherlands, the following cities have been participating in the ETDS: * [[Amsterdam]] (dancing society [[S.D.V. AmsterDance]]) * [[Delft]] (dancing society [[D.S.D.A. Blue Suede Shoes]]) * [[Eindhoven]] (dancing society [[E.S.D.V. Footloose]]) * [[Enschede]] (dancing society [[D.S.V. 4 Happy Feet]]) * [[Groningen (city)|Groningen]] (dancing society [[SSV The Blue Toes]]) * [[Leiden]] (dancing society [[S.D.A. Leidance]]) * [[Maastricht]] (dancing society [[M.S.D.V. Let's Dance]]) * [[Nijmegen]] (dancing society [[S.D.V.N. Dance Fever]]) * [[Rotterdam]] (dancing society [[Erasmus Dance Society]]) * [[Utrecht]] (dancing society [[U.S.D.V. U Dance]])
=== Other European countries === ==== Czech Republic ==== * [[Brno]]
==== Estonia ==== * [[Tallinn]]
==== France ==== * [[Antibes]]
==== Great Britain ==== * [[Cambridge]] * [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]] * [[Liverpool]]
==== Norway ==== * [[Oslo]] * [[Trondheim]]
==== Poland ==== * [[Lublin]]
==== Switzerland ==== * [[Winterthur]] * [[Zürich]]
=== Nations outside Europe === * [[Cape Town]]

{{infobox basketball club | name = Ezzahra Sports | color1 = white | color2 = #0033FF | logo = | nickname = | league = [[2014–15 Tunisian Men's Basketball League|2014–15 Tunisian League]] | founded = 1936 | dissolved = | history = | arena = Salle d'Ezzahra | capacity = | location = [[Ezzahra]], [[Tunisia]] | colors = {{color box|#0033FF}} {{color box|white}} | current = | sponsor = | president = | vice-presidents = | manager = | coach = | ownership = | championships = '''6''' [[Tunisian Division I Basketball League|Tunisian Leagues]]
'''5''' [[Tunisian Basketball Cup|Tunisian Cups]] | website = }} '''Ezzahra Sports''', or '''EZS''', is a [[Tunisia]]n professional [[basketball]] club from [[Ezzahra]]. The club competes in the [[Tunisian Division I Basketball League]]. ==History== Ezzahra has won the [[Tunisian Division I Basketball League|Tunisian League]] championship 6 times, in the years 1982, 1983, 1993, 1994, 1997, and 1999. They have also won the [[Tunisian Basketball Cup|Tunsian Cup]] 5 times, in the years 1985, 1988, 1991, 1995, and 1998. ==External links== *[http://www.afrobasket.com/team/Ezzahra_Sports/2875 AfricaBasket.com Team Page] [[Category:Basketball teams in Tunisia]] [[Category:Sport in Radès]] {{Tunisia-sport-stub}} {{basketball-team-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Aoti Main Stadium | image = Stade Olympique Guangdong.JPG | image_size = 300px | location = [[Guangzhou]], China | broke_ground = 31 December 1998{{cite web|url=http://www.gdsports.net/html/zsdw/2015_06_03_11_3992.html|title=广东省奥林匹克体育中心 |publisher=Guangdong Sports Bureau |date= |accessdate=2016-01-20}} | built = 1999–2001 | opened = 22 September 2001{{cite web|url=http://www.chinese-architecture.info/CA/CA-013.htm |title=Chinese Architecture- Guangdong Olympic Stadium |publisher=Chinese-architecture.info |date= |accessdate=2011-05-02}} | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Guangdong People's Government | operator = Guangdong Sports Bureau | surface = [[Lawn|Grass]] | construction_cost = 1.23 billion [[Renminbi|RMB]] | architect =[[Ellerbe Becket]][http://www.ellerbebecket.com/expertise/project/58/Guangdong_Olympic_Stadium.html Guangdong Olympic Stadium] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120529161243/http://www.ellerbebecket.com/expertise/project/58/Guangdong_Olympic_Stadium.html |date=29 May 2012 }} architect: [[Ellerbe Becket]] | former_names = | tenants = | seating_capacity = 80,012 }} {{Chinese|s=广东奥林匹克体育中心|t=廣東奧林匹克體育中心|p=Guǎngdōng Àolínpǐkè tǐyù zhōngxīn}} The '''Guangdong Olympic Centre Stadium''' or '''Aoti Main Stadium'''{{cite web |url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/cndy/2010-12/13/content_11690009.htm |title=Making the Aoti Main Stadium accessible |author= |date=19 December 2010 |work= |publisher=[[China Daily]] |accessdate=2010-12-19}} is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Guangzhou]], [[People's Republic of China]]. Currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches, the stadium was opened in 2001. It has a capacity of 80,012, making it the largest stadium in the country by seating capacity.{{cite web|url=http://www.chinese-architecture.info/CA/CA-013.htm |title=Chinese Architecture- Guangdong Olympic Stadium |publisher=Chinese-architecture.info |date= |accessdate=2011-05-02}} ==History== Guangdong Olympic Stadium broke ground on 31 December 1998 at the former site of [[Guangzhou Huangcun Airport|Huangcun Airport]]. It opened to the public for the [[National Games of China|Ninth National Games of China]] in 2001. It was originally planned to help host the [[2008 Summer Olympics]][http://www.architectureweek.com/2002/0501/design_1-1.html ArchitectureWeek - Design - China's Banner Stadium - 2002.0501] until a decision was made to construct the [[Beijing National Stadium|National Stadium]] in Beijing. The original design for the Guangdong Olympic Stadium was announced in 1999. Taking Guangzhou's nickname, the ''Flower City'', the American [[architecture|architectural]] firm of [[Ellerbe Becket]] designed Guangdong Olympic Stadium's sunscreen roof to resemble layers of petals on a [[flower]].{{cite web |url=http://www.archiplanet.org/wiki/Guangdong_Olympic_Stadium |title=Guangdong Olympic Stadium |publisher=Archiplanet |date= |accessdate=2011-05-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226181452/http://www.archiplanet.org/wiki/Guangdong_Olympic_Stadium |archivedate=26 February 2012 |df=dmy-all }} The design firm stated in its press release: "The stadium bowl grows out of the ground to a sculpted upper edge, like the [[petal]]s of a flower. Floating above the bowl is a shimmering [[ribbon]] of [[roof]] flowing like a [[wave]] over the [[chair|seat]]s. It parts at the ends and holds the [[Olympic flame]], suspended between the two ribbons. A [[hotel]] surrounds a circular opening in the roof that forms a vertical [[tower]] of light, which at night is visible for a great distance." The stadium's multi-colored seats are positioned in multiple sections that are visually connected via a ribbon pattern. ==Major events== *[[Guangzhou Evergrande F.C.|Guangzhou Pharmaceutical F.C.]] hosted the English [[Premier League]] champions [[Manchester United F.C.]] here on 27 July 2007. *[[Guangzhou Evergrande F.C.|Guangzhou Pharmaceutical F.C.]] hosted [[Chelsea F.C.]] on 23 July 2008 in Chelsea's first-ever trip to China. *The stadium hosted the athletics events of the [[2010 Asian Games]] and [[2010 Asian Para Games]], as well as the opening and closing ceremonies of the 2010 Asian Para Games. The ceremonies for 2010 Asian Games were held at a stand at [[Haixinsha Island (Tianhe District)|Haixinsha Island in the Tianhe District]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.worldstadiums.com/stadium_pictures/asia/china/guangdong_olympic.shtml Pictures of the Guangdong Olympic Stadium] *[http://www.architectureweek.com/2002/0501/design_1-1.html Architecture Week article about the stadium] {{s-start}} {{succession box | title=[[Asian Athletics Championships]]
Venue| before=[[Amman International Stadium]]
[[Amman]]| after=[[Kobe Universiade Memorial Stadium]]| years=[[2009 Asian Athletics Championships|2009]] }} {{end}} {{Guangzhou}} {{Asian Games stadia}} {{Coord|23|8|15.56|N|113|24|12.67|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Football venues in China]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in China]] [[Category:Sports venues in Guangzhou]] [[Category:Stadiums of the Asian Games]] [[Category:Venues of the 2010 Asian Games]] [[Category:Tianhe District]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in China]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2001]]

{{pp|small=yes}} {{Other uses|Millennium Centre (disambiguation){{!}}Millennium Centre}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Millennium Centar | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = Millennium Center | image = Vrsac, Centar Milenjum.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | full_name = | former_names = | location = [[Vršac]], [[Vojvodina]], [[Serbia]] | coordinates = {{Coord|45|7|5.05|N|21|18|38.52|E|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = April 5, 2001 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = Petar Arsić | project_manager = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 4,400 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[KK Vršac]] (2001–present)
[[ŽKK Vršac]] (2001–present) | website = http://www.millennium.rs/ }} The '''Millennium Centar''' ({{lang-sr|Центар Миленијум}}, {{lang|sr-Latn|Centar Milenijum}}) is a [[Multi-purpose stadium|multi-purpose]] indoor [[arena]] located in the city of [[Vršac]]. It is the home ground of [[basketball]] club [[KK Vršac]] and [[ŽKK Vršac]] and has a capacity of 4,400 seats. The arena is also used for concerts and other live entertainment. ==History== The arena was officially opened on April 5, 2001. The arena hosted the Group A of the [[EuroBasket 2005]], the basketball competitions of the [[2009 Summer Universiade]] and the Group D of the [[2012 European Men's Handball Championship]]. ==Concerts & events== * [[Svetlana Ražnatović|Svetlana Ceca Ražnatović]] performed a concert as part of her [[Poziv Tour]] promoting her album [[Poziv]] on 5. April 2014. ==See also== *[[List of indoor arenas in Serbia]] ==References== http://www.millennium.rs/sport.asp ==External links== * [http://www.millennium.rs/ Official website] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Serbia]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Serbia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Vojvodina]] [[Category:Sport in Vršac]] [[Category:KK Hemofarm]] [[Category:2012 European Women's Handball Championship]] [[Category:Buildings and structures celebrating the third millennium]] [[Category:2001 establishments in Serbia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2001]]
