revision.text:
[[File:Cliffside Hockey Team IAHU team champions, Allan Cup holders, amateur champions of the world,1909 (HS85-10-20692).jpg|thumb|right|205px|Ottawa Cliffsides in 1909.]]
The '''Ottawa Cliffsides''' were a senior [[ice hockey]] team that played in the [[Inter-Provincial Amateur Hockey Union]] from 1908–1911.
They were the first winner of the [[Allan Cup]] in [[1909 Allan Cup|1909]] when the cup was given to the winner of the Inter-provincial Hockey League. [[Alf Smith (ice hockey)|Alf Smith]] coached the Ottawa Cliffsides to win the first [[Allan Cup]] in March 1909, only to lose it to [[Queen's University]] in a challenge.
The Cliffsides played for only three seasons in the Inter-provincial League. They then reappeared in the [[Ottawa City Senior League]] in 1919-20 before disappearing for good.
==Season-by-season results== ===Inter-Provincial Amateur Hockey Union=== Season Games Won Lost Tied Points GoalsFor GoalsAgainst Standing Playoffs 1908-09 6 5 1 0 10 56 43 1st Lost Final 1909-10 6 4 2 0 8 59 43 Tied 1st Lost Final 1910-11 6 5 1 0 10 50 24 tied 1st Central Lost Final
===Ottawa City Senior League=== Season Games Won Lost Tied Points GoalsFor GoalsAgainst Standing Playoffs 1919-20 7 4 3 0 8 10 8 4th Group 1 out of playoffs

revision.text:
{{Coord|39.252899|-76.712267|display=title}} {{Infobox venue | name = Retriever Activities Center | nickname = RAC | native_name = | native_name_lang = | fullname = | former names = UMBC Fieldhouse | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = Image:RetrieverActivitiesCenter.jpg | image_size = 300px | image_alt = | caption = The Retriever Activities Center prior to the 2008 [[America East Conference]] Championship Game | pushpin_map = | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | address = 1000 Hilltop Cir, Baltimore, MD 21250 | location = | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | type = | genre = | broke_ground = | built = | opened = <!-- {{Start date|1973|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[University of Maryland, Baltimore County]] | operator = | surface = | scoreboard = | production = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | seating_type = | capacity = 4,024 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | field_shape = | acreage = | volume = | tenants = [[UMBC Retrievers]] | embedded = | website = <!-- {{URL|http://umbcretrievers.com/information/facilities/racarena/index}} --> | publictransit = [[Route 77 (MTA Maryland)|MTA 77]] }}
'''Retriever Activities Center''' is a 4,024-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Catonsville, Maryland]]. The arena opened in 1973. It was home to the [[UMBC Retrievers]] basketball and volleyball teams, which represent the [[University of Maryland, Baltimore County]] in [[NCAA Division I]] athletics, from its opening until the larger [[UMBC Event Center]] opened on campus in February 2018.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/sports/college/basketball/mens/bs-sp-umbc-vermont-event-center-20180124-story.html|title=New UMBC Event Center to open for Feb. 3 men's basketball game vs. Vermont|first=Jonas|last=Shaffer|newspaper=[[Baltimore Sun]] |date=January 24, 2018 |accessdate=February 1, 2018}}</ref> It hosted the 2008 [[America East Conference]] men's basketball tournament final.
==Background== The Retriever Activities Center (RAC) has numerous purposes for UMBC, both for athletics and student life. The aforementioned UMBC Event Center, located at the intersection of Hilltop Circle and Commons Drive, adjacent to [[Giffen Hill]], replaced the RAC for various activities including varsity basketball and volleyball games, student-athlete health, student events, and commencement ceremonies.<ref>http://fm.umbc.edu/projects/retriever-event-center/</ref>
[[File:Retriever Activities Center Exterior.jpg|left|thumb|The entrance to the RAC in December 2017.]]
The RAC includes:<ref>http://recreation.umbc.edu/inside-recreation/recreation-hours-the-rac/</ref> *'''[[UMBC Aquatic Complex]]''', a state-of-the-art swimming pool complex (indoor and outdoor), as well as locker rooms and showers. *'''RAC Arena''', formerly the university's main arena; previously used for basketball and volleyball games and commencement ceremonies, and still used for other events. *'''RAC Gymnasium''', the student gym complex includes a weight room, cardio balcony, and fitness studio. *'''Arena Track''', an indoor track encircling the main arena used for running and jogging. *'''Outdoor Tennis Courts''', located behind the RAC, the Outdoor Tennis Courts offer an additional amenity to the center.
==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]]
==References== <references />
==External links== *[http://www.umbcretrievers.com/info/facilities/ UMBC Retrievers Facilities]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = Rhone Apparel Inc. | logo = RhoneLogo2017.png | logo_size = | logo_padding = | logo_alt =Rhone Corporate Logo | logo_caption =Rhone logo 2017 | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_name = | type = | industry = | founded = 2014 | founders = Nate Checketts, Carras Holmstead, Casey Edgar | hq_location = 484 Pacific St. | hq_location_city = [[Stamford, Connecticut]] | hq_location_country = [[United States]] | num_locations =3 | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = Nate Checketts <small>([[Chief executive officer|CEO]])</small> | products = Men's [[sportswear (activewear)]] | brands = Rhone, SilverTech, GoldFusion | owner = <!-- or: | owners = --> | num_employees = 30 | num_employees_year = 2017 | website = {{URL|http://www.rhone.com/}} | slogan = }} '''Rhone Apparel''' (referred to simply as '''Rhone''') is an [[United States|American]] [[startup company]] producing and selling men's [[sportswear (activewear)]]. Its product line is intended for high-income, active men between 25 and 50 years of age, who look for activewear that is functional and attractive. The company uses premium custom fabrics, which include silver thread that provides permanent antibacterial and anti-odorant protection.<ref name=Bloomberg /><ref name=News />
All of Rhone's products are designed in [[Connecticut]], with a warehouse in [[Utah]].<ref name=FAQ /> Rhone has been called "2016's hottest men's activewear brand."<ref name=Forbes />
== History ==
Rhone was founded in [[New Canaan, Connecticut]], in 2014 by Nate Checketts, an ex-[[National Football League|NFL]] employee, Kyle McClure, a former [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[lacrosse]] player, and two other founders.<ref name=Post>{{cite web |url = https://nypost.com/2014/09/17/athletic-gear-fit-for-superman/ |title = Athletic gear fit for Superman |author = Stephanie Smith |publisher = New York Post |date = 17 September 2014 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref> The company's name comes from the [[Rhône|river and region]] in Europe.<ref name=Ruden>{{cite web |url = http://www.therudenreport.com/top-of-the-line-two-new-canaan-football-graduates-looking-to-make-it-big-in-mens-activewear/ |title = Top Of The Line: Two New Canaan Football Graduates Looking To Make It Big In Men's Activewear |author = Dave Ruden |publisher = The Ruden Report |date = 28 July 2014 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref> The founders were inspired by the fact that the [[Rhône]] is not only aesthetically beautiful, but was also highly functional for the surrounding civilizations.<ref name=Story>{{cite web |url = http://www.rhone.com/pages/our-story |title = Our Story |publisher = Rhone Apparel |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref>
The company launched as a [[Online shopping|web-only retailer]], but partnered with [[Bloomingdale's]] in November 2014 to sell in five locations. In 2015, it entered 127 retail storefronts, selling at such retailers as [[Nordstrom]], [[Equinox Fitness|Equinox]] and [[CorePower Yoga]].<ref name=Retailer /> Rhone launched its first pop-up store in [[New York City]].<ref name=Shopify>{{cite web |url = https://www.shopify.com/enterprise/93488390-how-rhone-apparel-uses-pop-up-stores-to-create-3d-customer-experiences-grow-500 |title = How Rhone Apparel Uses Pop-up Stores to Create 3D Customer Experiences & Grow 500% |author = Nick Winkler |publisher = Shopify |date = 19 February 2016 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref>
Rhone experienced sharp growth in 2015. In the month of November, it earned 62% of its 2014 revenue. Its website traffic rose by 350% from 2014 to 2015.<ref name=Bloomberg /> Wholesale became the primary driver of the company's 500% growth over the year before that.<ref name=Retailer />
The company announced the closing of a $5 million [[Series A round|Series A financing]] in September 2015. The investors came from sports, media and fashion circles, including [[Steve Bornstein]], [[David Stern]], [[Ryen Russillo]], and [[Shane Battier]].<ref name=Forbes>{{cite web |url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/jasonbelzer/2015/11/11/move-over-lululemon-rhone-is-about-to-take-over-the-mens-activewear-market/#53f27eb1af86 |title = Move Over Lululemon, Rhone Is About To Take Over The Men's Activewear Market |author = Jason Belzer |publisher = Forbes |date = 11 November 2015 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref> Since its launch, Rhone has raised a total of $6.2 million.<ref name=Retailer>{{cite web |url = https://www.internetretailer.com/2016/01/13/activewear-retailer-rhone-apparel-grows-500-2015 |title = Activewear retailer Rhone Apparel grows 500% in 2015 |author = Fareeha Ali |publisher = Internet Retailer |date = 13 January 2016 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref>
In February 2016, Rhone organized the purchase of a building from 1892 in [[Stamford, Connecticut|Stamford]] to convert it to a new headquarters.<ref name=Stamford>{{cite web |url = http://www.stamfordadvocate.com/business/article/Just-for-men-Rhone-picks-Stamford-for-new-6801894.php#photo-9341424 |title = Just for men: Rhone picks Stamford for new headquarters |author = Alexander Soule |publisher = Stamford Advocate |date = 3 February 2016 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref> At the time, about 65% of its business was online.<ref name=Bloomberg>{{cite web |url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/videos/2015-12-23/rhone-apparel-gets-into-the-activewear-game |title = Rhone Apparel Gets Into the Activewear Game |publisher = Bloomberg Business |date = 23 December 2015 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref>
== Profile and products ==
Rhone is targeting sophisticated, high-income, active men that look for activewear that is both functional and attractive.<ref name=Shopify /> Its targeted demographic is between 25 and 50 years of age.<ref name=Bloomberg /> Its buyers are diverse, including a unit that [[War in Afghanistan (2015-present)|defuses bombs in Afghanistan]] as well as [[marathon]] winners.<ref name=Ruden /> The fitness clothes can also be used for day-to-day activities.<ref name=Complex>{{cite web |url = http://www.complex.com/style/2014/11/rhone-presents-activewear-line-that-combats-odor |title = Rhone's Activewear Will Fight Sweat Stains and Odor Permanently |author = Joshua Espinoza |publisher = Complex |date = 19 November 2014 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref>
The company's product line aims to separate the brand from competitors like [[Lululemon Athletica|Lululemon]], [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] and [[Under Armour]], whose premium men's offerings are more generic and less available.<ref name=Forbes /> The company uses superior materials in order to create clothes that last longer than the average product. While the average mass brands spend between $2 and $4 a yard for fabrics, some of Rhone's fabrics cost $15 per yard.<ref name=Ruden /><ref name=Bloomberg />
When the company founders began researching [[antimicrobial]] fabrics, they found that weaving silver into cloth created permanent antibacterial and anti-odorant protection, unlike typical anti-odorant treatments which last for 15 to 20 washes.<ref name=News>{{cite web |url = http://connecticut.news12.com/news/growing-new-canaan-startup-rhone-apparel-to-move-headquarters-to-stamford-1.11514454?pts=174621 |title = Growing New Canaan startup to move to Stamford |publisher = News 12 Connecticut |date = 26 February 2016 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref> SilverTech is the brand name of the silver thread that is woven into the company's fabrics.<ref name=FAQ>{{cite web |url = http://www.rhone.com/pages/support |title = Frequently Asked Questions |publisher = Rhone Apparel |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref> In fact, silver has been [[medical uses of silver|used as an antiseptic]] since [[Hippocrates]]. The kind of silver threading Rhone uses was initially developed by the [[United States Army|American military]] for [[Iraq War|soldiers in Iraq]].<ref name=Hook>{{cite web |url = http://www.insidehook.com/nation/rhone-apparel/ |title = Right on Track |publisher = Inside Hook |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref> When it launched, Rhone got numerous orders from army bases, as captains were ordering the gear for troops to wear during training.<ref name=Post />
Clothing details include strategically placed breathable mesh venting panels;<ref name=Marge>{{cite web |url = http://www.dmarge.com/2014/12/5-activewear-brands-loving-moment.html |title = 5 Activewear Brands We're Loving At The Moment |author = Elyse Romano |publisher = D'Marge |date = 11 December 2014 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref> [[silicone]] gel on the drawstring;<ref name=Hook /> a media pocket; and a thick, tall and padded waistband on the shorts.<ref name=Jeans>{{cite web |url = http://www.jeansandties.com/rhone-apparel-review/ |title = Rhone Apparel Review |author = Dominic Bonvissuto |publisher = Jeans & Ties |date = 28 October 2014 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref> The clothes have stitched-in inspirational messages, such as "Don't Die Without a Few Scars" or "What We Do in Life Echoes in Eternity."<ref name=Jeans /> [[overlock|Flatlock stitching]], where the seams lie flat with edges of fabric butting together rather than folding together, is used to avoid [[chafing (skin)|chafing]].<ref name=Bloomberg /> The Polartec Power Dry patented construction creates a fabric that is quick [[capillary action|wicking]] to improve breathability and performance.<ref name=Forbes /> The clothes have a combination of open and zippered pockets. The fit is a medium between XXL and compression.<ref name=WSJ>{{cite web |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/rhone-apparel-makes-activewear-just-for-men-1405699125 |title = Rhone Apparel Makes Activewear Just for Men |author = David Colman |publisher = The Wall Street Journal |date = 18 July 2014 |accessdate = 28 March 2016}}</ref>
Other apparel includes the Rhone Flask, which keeps drinks cold for 24 hours and hot for 12 hours.<ref name=Bloomberg />
Rhone's style names come from masculine icons, like the Durden T-shirt after [[Fight Club (novel)#Tyler Durden|"Fight Club" character Tyler Durden]],<ref name=WSJ /> or the Mako short after the shark from ''[[The Old Man and the Sea]]''.<ref name=Ruden />
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== External links == *{{Official website|http://www.rhone.com/}}
[[Category:American companies established in 2014]] [[Category:Sportswear brands]] [[Category:Companies based in Stamford, Connecticut]] [[Category:Companies based in Connecticut]] [[Category:Sporting goods manufacturers of the United States]]

revision.comment: /* Rinkball */
revision.text:
:''Not to be confused with rink hockey, which is another name for [[Roller hockey (quad)|roller hockey]] on quad skates.'' [[File:Bandystick.gif|thumb|right|A (rink) bandy stick and ball]] [[File:Bandy ball (Orange).JPG|thumb|The ball]] [[File:УФХМР 2013.jpg|thumb|Rink bandy in [[Dnipro]]]] '''Rink bandy''' and '''rinkball''' are variants of [[bandy]] played on significantly smaller [[ice rink]]s. While a [[bandy field|bandy rink]] is about the same size as a [[football pitch]], rink bandy is played on [[ice hockey rink]]s.
Rink bandy originated in [[Sweden]] in the 1960s and was originally called '''hockeybockey'''.<ref>[http://www.skelleftea.org/forening/spif/rbandy/r_start.htm Skelleftepolisens IF - ''Rinkbandy''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040121040252/http://www.skelleftea.org/forening/spif/rbandy/r_start.htm |date=2004-01-21 }}</ref> With the arrival of indoor ice hockey arenas, it was a way for [[bandy]] players to practice on ice a longer time of the year; as [[bandy field]]s are larger, they were still only made outdoors in the wintertime when artificial freezing was not necessary.
The game uses a [[bandy ball]] and bandy sticks. The goalkeeper has no stick. As in hockey, a game lasts 60 minutes, but is composed of either two 30 minute halves or three 20 minute periods. Similar rules to normal bandy are used, but they are simplified to increase the pace of the game. [[Checking (ice hockey)|Checking]] is prohibited, making the sport relatively safer than its relatives. Because of the smaller playing area, there are fewer players, normally six a side. In the [[Bandy in the United States#League_play|USA Rink Bandy League]], five players are used because of the smaller ice hockey rinks there.
== Organisation == [[File:Balashikha Arena.jpg|right|220px|thumb|[[Balashikha Arena]], where the 2017 Russian Rink Bandy Cup took place.<ref>https://translate.google.co.uk/translate?hl=en&sl=ru&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.rusbandy.ru%2Fnews%2F11118%2F</ref>]] Rink bandy is governed by the [[Federation of International Bandy]]. In its quest to have bandy accepted into the programme of the [[Winter Olympics]], rink bandy is an important way for the Federation of International Bandy to gain more members, thus also spreading bandy, since many countries, which lack a full-size field and where the game is still new, only play rink bandy at home but still participate in the [[Bandy World Championship]].
As artificially frozen and indoor bandy arenas have become more prevalent, the interest for rink bandy has dwindled in the main bandy-playing nations (Russia, Sweden, Finland, Norway). There are still several rink bandy tournaments in [[Russia]],<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9qhuUv9bBQg Video of the 2nd half between [[Lokomotiv Orenburg]] and [[CSK VVS Samara (ice hockey)|CSK VVS Samara]] in the 2011 Russian Rink Bandy Cup]</ref> including the Patriarch Cup ({{lang|ru|Турнир на призы Святейшего Патриарха Московского и всея Руси}}<ref>http://uniorsport.ru/bandy_kp_2017.php</ref>) for children at [[Moscow]]'s [[Red Square]].<ref>https://translate.google.co.uk/translate?hl=en&sl=ru&u=https://pravoslavie.ru/68869.html</ref>
A world cup for rink bandy clubs was held every year from 1984-1998 in [[Hofors]], Sweden, and called [[Hofors World Cup]]. Rink bandy was included in the programme of the 2012 European Company Sports Games<ref>http://www.visitsodradalarna.se/en/ECSG-2012/Sports/Rinkbandy/</ref> and a European championship existed, though there is currently no top-level international competition. However, in 2017 the Federation of International Bandy decided to hold an international tournament for developing bandy countries in [[Nymburk]], [[Czech Republic]]<ref>[http://www.worldbandy.com/newspost_8333.html European Rinkbandy Cup in Nymburk, Czech Republic]</ref><ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7FhQ8r0ES5o Video from the whole 2017 European Rink Bandy Cup final]</ref> and an international rink bandy club competition called Dniprobandy has been organised by the [[Ukrainian Bandy and Rink bandy Federation]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://worldbandy.com/news.asp?newsid=524&title=Information%20about%20the%20second%20international%20rink%20bandy%20tournament|title= Information about the second international rink bandy tournament|publisher= Federation of International Bandy|date= 2013-07-04|accessdate= 9 August 2015}}</ref> In Germany, the [[List of German rink bandy champions|national bandy championship]] is played under rink bandy rules.
==Rinkball== In the 1970s rinkball, which is played by more ice hockey-like sticks, grew from being played in local tournaments by villagers around Finland to national-level competitions involving 100 teams or more. The sport first gained international attention in 1984 when teams from [[Finland]] and Sweden hosted one another. The International Rinkball Association was formed soon after, and in the late 1990s included [[Russia]], Sweden, [[Kazakhstan]], [[Estonia]], [[Switzerland]], [[Hungary]], Finland and the [[United States]].<ref name="Rinkball history"/> The Finnish Rinkball Federation has 1000 teams, including women, men and children. Play is divided into eight male divisions, two female divisions, and children's play is divided by age.<ref>[http://www.kaukalopalloliitto.fi/ Finnish Rinkball and Ringette Federation]</ref> The first World Championship Games for men was held in [[Omsk]], Russia, in 1998.<ref name="Rinkball history">[http://rinkball.ru/history/hist3.htm Rinkball history]</ref>
The Rinkball League in Finland publishes a magazine called ''Liiga Extra'', which offers international coverage of tournaments, equipment, and tips. In Finland, leagues and a national championship is held annually (as of 2016).

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Segnette Field | nickname = | image = File:AlarioCenterOct09Field.jpg | image_size = | location = Segnette Blvd
[[Westwego, Louisiana|Westwego, LA]] | coordinates = {{Coord|29.9035|-90.1644|type:landmark_region:US-LA|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 2002 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Artificial Turf | construction_cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | tenants = [[Loyola Wolfpack]] (baseball) (2003–present)
[[Louisiana High School Athletic Association|LHSAA]] (baseball)
[[American Legion Baseball|American Legion]] (baseball) | seating_capacity = 750 | dimensions = Left Field: {{convert|325|ft|m}}
Center Field: {{convert|400|ft|m}}
Right Field: {{convert|335|ft|m}} }} '''Segnette Field''' is a 750-seat [[baseball]] stadium located in the [[New Orleans metropolitan area]] town of [[Westwego, Louisiana]].{{cite web|url=http://gnosports.dreamhosters.com/facilities_app/venueDetail.php?vid=54|title=Segnette Field|publisher=gnosports.dreamhosters.com|accessdate=2018-03-05}}{{cite web|url=https://www.visitjeffersonparish.com/listing/alario-center-segnette-field/335/|title=Alario Field-Segnette Field|publisher=visitjeffersonparish.com|accessdate=2018-03-09}} The stadium includes a grandstand, press box, public address system and scoreboard. The baseball field features artificial turf with a clay pitcher's mound. The stadium opened in May 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.nba.com/pelicans/media/12_MIscellaneous.pdf|title=Bayou Segnette Sports Complex|publisher=nba.com|accessdate=2018-03-09}} It is the current home of the [[Loyola Wolf Pack#Baseball|Loyola Wolf Pack baseball team]].{{cite web|url=http://www.loyolawolfpack.com/facilities|title=Athletic Facility Information|publisher=loyolawolfpack.com|accessdate=2018-03-09}}{{cite web|url=http://baseball.isport.com/baseball-fields/us/louisiana/westwego/loyola-university-segnette-field-1147441|title=Alario Field-Segnette Field|publisher=isport.com|accessdate=2018-03-09}} College baseball, [[Louisiana High School Athletic Association|LHSAA]] high school baseball games and [[American Legion]] baseball games are played at the stadium.{{cite web|url=http://geauxcolonels.com/news/2013/5/11/BASE_0511135638.aspx|title=Colonels To Play Doubleheader At Segnette Field In Westwego|publisher=geauxcolonels.com|accessdate=2018-03-09}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theadvocate.com/baton_rouge/sports/high_schools/article_71276fbe-651d-11e7-a560-d7a5f44c8c29.html|title=American Legion Southeast Regional tournament scores, schedule|publisher=theadvocate.com|accessdate=2018-03-09}} The stadium is also used for festivals.{{cite web|url=http://www.wdsu.com/article/westbank-heritage-festival-returns-for-second-year/3394998|title=Westbank Heritage Festival returns for second year|publisher=wdsu.com|accessdate=2018-03-09}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.loyolawolfpack.com/sport/0/3.php Loyola Wolf Pack baseball] {{Loyola University New Orleans}} [[Category:Baseball venues in New Orleans]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Loyola Wolf Pack baseball]] [[Category:High school baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2002]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Louisiana]]

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Springs Brooks Stadium | nickname = ''The Palace'' | image = | image_size = | caption = | location = 965 One Landon Loop
[[Conway, South Carolina]] | coordinates = {{Coord|33.7935|-79.0152|type:landmark_region:US-SC|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = 2011 | opened = February 13, 2015 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Coastal Carolina University]] | operator = {{nowrap|Coastal Carolina University}} | surface = Natural grass | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]15.2 million | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Coastal Carolina Chanticleers baseball|Coastal Carolina]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (2015–present) | seating_capacity = 5,400 (2016-present)
2,500 (2015) | record_attendance = 4,130 (March 20, 2018) }} {{Location map |USA |relief = 1 |label = Conway |lat = 33.7935 |long = -79.0152 |caption = Location in the [[United States]] |marksize = 5 |mark = |float = |background= |width = 240 }} {{Location map |USA South Carolina |relief = 1 |label = Conway |lat = 33.7935 |long = -79.0152 |caption = Location in [[South Carolina]] |marksize = 5 |mark = |float = |background= |width = 160 }} '''Springs Brooks Stadium/Vrooman Field''' is a [[baseball]] [[Baseball park|park]] in the [[Southeastern United States|southeastern]] [[United States]], located on the campus of [[Coastal Carolina University]] in [[Conway, South Carolina]]. It is the home field of the [[Coastal Carolina Chanticleers baseball|Coastal Carolina Chanticleers]] of the [[Sun Belt Conference]]. The {{convert|33,000|sqft|adj=on}} baseball project includes 2,500 permanent seats, with the potential to accommodate between 5,000-6,000 for major events like the [[NCAA Division I Baseball Championship|NCAA postseason tournament]]. ==History== Formerly known as '''Charles Watson Stadium - Vrooman Field''', the facility underwent renovations in 2004, which included a new scoreboard, a new fence, a new infield, and a new sound system. The field also had new lights installed in 2005. In 2008, new seats and new turf outside of the bases and home plate were installed. The clubhouse was also renovated with new lockers, a new lounge and a new training facility. Stadium capacity was expanded to nearly 2,200 during the 2008 season, with the addition of a right field deck dubbed "The Rooster's Nest." The stadium hosted an [[2008 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament#Cary Super Regional|NCAA Regional]] for the first time in [[2008 NCAA Division I Baseball Tournament#Cary Super Regional|2008]]. Following the 2012 season, the venue underwent major renovations and Coastal Carolina played their home games in 2013 and 2014 in nearby [[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina|Myrtle Beach]] at [[TicketReturn.com Field]]. The ballpark officially reopened in 2015 under its new name, '''Springs Brooks Stadium - Vrooman Field''', on February 13. Its first game was between [[Maryland Terrapins baseball|Maryland]] and [[Western_Kentucky_Hilltoppers_and_Lady_Toppers#Baseball|Western Kentucky]] as part of the Caravelle Resort Tournament that CCU hosted. Later that day, Coastal Carolina defeated [[Old Dominion Monarchs baseball|Old Dominion]] 4–0 in front of a crowd of 1,736, their first home game since renovations were completed.http://www.goccusports.com/sports/m-basebl/recaps/021315aaa.html The attendance record of 3,086 was set on March 24, 2015, when CCU defeated [[2015 South Carolina Gamecocks baseball team|South Carolina]] 9–8 in {{nowrap|eleven innings.http://www.goccusports.com/sports/m-basebl/recaps/032415aaa.html}} The diamond has an unorthodox southeasterly alignment (home plate to center field); the recommended orientation is {{nowrap|east-northeast.{{cite web|url=http://mlb.mlb.com/documents/0/8/0/268272080/2018_Official_Baseball_Rules.pdf |publisher=Major League Baseball |title=Official Baseball Rules: 2.01 Layout of the Field |date=2018 |page=2}}}} The [[elevation]] of the field is approximately {{convert|40|ft|0|spell=in}} above [[sea level]]. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.goccusports.com/facilities/watson-stadium.html Charles L. Watson Stadium/Vrooman Field] *[http://www.goccusports.com/facilities/springs-brooks-stadium.html Springs Brooks Stadium/Vrooman Field] {{Coastal Carolina Chanticleers baseball navbox}} {{Sun Belt Conference baseball venue navbox |state=collapsed}} {{South Carolina NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Horry County, South Carolina]] [[Category:Baseball venues in South Carolina]] [[Category:Coastal Carolina Chanticleers baseball]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Conway, South Carolina]] [[Category:2015 establishments in South Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2015]] {{SouthCarolina-baseball-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox country at games | NOC = VEN | NOCname = [[Venezuelan Olympic Committee]] | year = 1999 | date = 23 July – 8 August 1999 | games = Pan American Games | location = [[1999 Pan American Games|Winnipeg]] | competitors = | sports = | flagbearer = | officials = | gold = 7 | silver = 16 | bronze = 17 | rank = 8 | appearances = auto | app_begin_year = | seealso = | website = [http://www.covoficial.com.ve/ www.covoficial.com.ve] }} The '''[[1999 Pan American Games|13th Pan American Games]]''' were held in [[Winnipeg, Manitoba]], Canada from July 23 to August 8, 1999. ==Medals== ===[[Image:Gold medal america.svg|20px]] Gold=== {{Pan American Games medal title|year=1999|image = Karate pictogram.svg|event=Karate}} *Men's Kumite (– 75 kg): [[Ricardo Pérez (karate)|Ricardo Pérez]] *Women's Kumite (– 60 kg): [[María Wayow]] ===[[Image:Silver medal america.svg|20px]] Silver=== {{Pan American Games medal title|year=1999|image = Bowling pictogram.svg|event=Bowling}} *Women's Singles: [[Alicia Marcano]] {{Pan American Games medal title|year=1999|image = Boxing pictogram.svg|event=Boxing}} *Men's Bantamweight (– 54 kg): [[Nehomar Cermeno]] {{Pan American Games medal title|year=1999|image = Karate pictogram.svg|event=Karate}} *Men's Kata: [[José Antonio Díaz (karateka)|José Antonio Díaz]] *Men's Kumite (– 70 kg): [[Jaime Noguera]] ===[[Image:Bronze medal america.svg|20px]] Bronze=== {{Pan American Games medal title|year=1999|image = Boxing pictogram.svg|event=Boxing}} *Men's Lightweight (– 60 kg): [[Patrick López]] *Men's Welterweight (– 67 kg): [[Charlie Navarro]] *Men's Middleweight (– 75 kg): [[Jim Rodriguez]] {{Pan American Games medal title|year=1999|image = Karate pictogram.svg|event=Karate}} *Men's Kumite (– 60 kg): [[Eduardo Noguera]] *Men's Kumite (– 70 kg): [[Jean Carlos Peña]] *Women's Kata: [[Ana Martínez (karateka)|Ana Martínez]] ==See also== * [[Venezuela at the 2000 Summer Olympics]]

page.title: Village of Lisle-Benedictine University Sports Complex

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Village of Lisle-Benedictine University Sports Complex | logo_image = | image = [[File:2013-06-09 BenedictineUniversity Scoreboard.JPG|300px|alt=Benedictine University Stadium Scoreboard]] | caption = Benedictine University Stadium scoreboard | location = Benedictine University campus, 5700 College Road, [[Lisle, Illinois]] 60532 | coordinates = {{Coord|41|46|45|N|88|5|52|W|type:edu_region:US-IL|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | opened = 2005 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = artificial surface for football and soccer; natural grass for baseball and softball | construction_cost = under US$ 9 million | architect = [[DLR Group]] | project_manager = | services engineer = | general_contractor = Walsh Construction | former_names = | tenants = [[Benedictine University|Benedictine Eagles]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[NCAA Division III|D-III]]) (2005–present)
[[Chicago Machine (MLL)|Chicago Machine]] ([[Major League Lacrosse|MLL]]) (2006)
[[Chicago Red Stars]] ([[Women's Premier Soccer League|WPSL]]/[[Women's Premier Soccer League Elite|WPSLE]]/[[National Women's Soccer League|NWSL]]) (2011–2015)
[[DuPage Drones]] ([[Prospect League|PL]]) (2015-2016)
local high schools |}} '''Village of Lisle-Benedictine University Sports Complex''' is a facility for football, soccer, baseball, softball, and track and field. The multimillion-dollar sports-complex on the campus of [[Benedictine University]], in the [[Lisle, Illinois|Village of Lisle, Illinois]] is a collaborative effort between the university and the village.{{Cite web| url=http://www.villageoflisle.org/home/index.asp?page=584| title=Village of Lisle/Benedictine University Sports Complex| publisher=villageoflisle.org}} Located just outside [[Chicago]], the sports-complex is home to the sport teams of Benedictine University Athletics.{{Cite web| url=http://athletics.ben.edu/sports/2009/6/21/GEN_0621092628.aspx?id=9| title=The Village of Lisle-Benedictine University Sports Complex| publisher=THE OFFICIAL SITE OF BENEDICTINE UNIVERSITY ATHLETICS}} It was the home stadium of [[Chicago Red Stars]] women's soccer club from [[2015 Chicago Red Stars season|2011]] to [[2015 Chicago Red Stars season|2015]]. The stadium was home to [[Major League Lacrosse]]'s [[Chicago Machine (MLL)|Chicago Machine]] in their 2006 inaugural season. Local high schools host football and soccer games in the stadium. A [[baseball]] stadium and a [[softball]] stadium are also included in the complex. The baseball stadium is home to Benedictine University Eagles and the DuPage County Hounds{{Cite web| url=http://dupagehounds.com/home/| title=Official Site of the Dupage Hounds| publisher=dupagehounds.com}} of the Midwest Collegiate League. ==Stadium complex== [[File:Benedictine University baseball practice field.jpg|thumb|350px|left|Benedictine University baseball practice field]] The 3,000-seat main stadium for [[American football]] and [[Association football|soccer]] is also a fine athletics facility with an artificial playing surface, a nine-lane track, electronic scoreboard and message board, and electric lights. The main press box, four luxury suites and viewing sundecks are above the seating gallery. Natural grass practice fields and throwing venues for baseball and softball are directly adjacent to the main stadium. The baseball stadium seats 1,000, including 800 chairs, and has handicap accessible areas on the main concourse. The baseball field measures 325 feet to the outfield fence. Oversized dugouts allow for maximum player comfort. The stadium features a large electronic scoreboard and message board, and a public address system provides coverage to the stands and concourse. The sports complex was built by Walsh Construction, and the architect was [[DLR Group]].{{Cite web| url=http://www.walshgroup.com/portfolio/commercial+building/education/sports-complex-at-benedictine-university-in-lisle.html| title=Sports Complex at Benedictine University in Lisle| publisher=walshgroup.com}} The complex was completed in November 2004. ==Images== {{wide_image|2013-06-09 BenedictineUniversity Stadium.JPG|1200px|Benedictine University main stadium|alt=Benedictine University main stadium|dir=rtl}} {{wide_image|Benedictine University baseball stadium.jpg|1200px|Benedictine University baseball stadium|alt=Benedictine University baseball stadium|dir=rtl}} {{wide_image|2015-04-18 BenedictineUniversityFieldAthleticsFacilities.JPG|1200px|Facilities for field athletics north of the main stadium and baseball practice field|alt=Facilities for field athletics in Village of Lisle-Benedictine University Sports Complex}} ==See also== * [[Benedictine University]] * [[Lisle, Illinois|Village of Lisle, Illinois]] * [[Chicago Red Stars]] ==References== [[Jilin]], China | built = August 2010[http://www.yanjinews.com/html/news/yanjinews/2013/1104/34284.html 延吉市新体育场完成草坪及朔胶跑道铺设工作] | opened = November 2013[http://www.jl.xinhuanet.com/2012jlpd/2013-11/08/c_118055639.htm 延吉市全民健身中心体育场竣工] | renovated = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture Government | operator = Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture Sports Bureau | surface = [[Grass]] | construction_cost = 220 million [[Renminbi|RMB]] | architect = | tenants =
[[Yanbian Funde F.C.]] | seating_capacity = 30,000 }} The '''Yanji Nationwide Fitness Centre Stadium''' ([[Simplified Chinese]]: 延吉市全民健身中心体育场), also known as '''Yanji New Stadium''' ([[Simplified Chinese]]: 延吉新体育场) or '''Yanji People's Stadium''' ([[Simplified Chinese]]: 延吉人民体育场), is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Yanji]], [[Yanbian Korean Autonomous Prefecture]], [[Jilin]], China. It is currently used mostly for [[association football]] matches. The stadium holds 30,000 people, and is the home stadium of [[Yanbian Funde F.C.]]. It was built in August 2010 to replace the [[Yanji People's Stadium]] and opened in November 2013, at a cost of 220 million [[Renminbi|RMB]].[http://news.xwh.cn/news/system/2013/11/05/010410617.shtml 延吉市全民健身中心体育场即将交付使用] ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord missing|Jilin}} [[Category:Football venues in China]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in China]] [[Category:Sports venues in Jilin]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in China]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2013]] {{PRChina-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Švyturio Arena | logo_image = Švyturys Arena logo.png | logo_size = 180px | image = ŠvyturioArenaKlp01.JPG | nickname = | address = Dubysos g. 10 | location = [[Klaipėda]], [[Lithuania]] | coordinates = {{coord|55|41|13|N|21|9|21|E|display=inline,title|region:LT_type:landmark}} | broke_ground = October, 2009 | opened = July 28, 2011 | owner = [[Švyturys]], [[Klaipėda city municipality]] | construction_cost = [[Euro|€]]16 Million | general_contractor = Vėtrūna | architect = AB „Miestprojektas“ Kaunas | tenants = [[BC Neptūnas]] | seating_capacity = [[Basketball]]: 6,200
[[Ice hockey]]: 4,416
[[Concerts]]: 7,500
[[Boxing]]/[[Wrestling]]: 6,512 | website = {{URL|svyturioarena.lt}} }} '''Švyturio Arena''' ''(English: Lighthouse Arena)'' is an indoor [[arena]] in [[Klaipėda]], [[Lithuania]]. The arena is named after the company ''[[Švyturys]]'', which bought the rights for the name. The capacity of the [[catamaran]]-shaped arena is 6,200 seats for [[basketball]] games, 4,416 for [[ice hockey]] games, 6,512 for [[boxing]]/[[wrestling]] matches, and 7,450 seats for [[concerts]]. ==History== Klaipėda Arena held [[EuroBasket 2011 Group D|Group D]] matches of the 37th [[EuroBasket 2011|FIBA European Basketball Championship]], from 31 August, to 5 September 2011. == External links== * {{official|http://www.svyturioarena.lt}} * [http://www.miestai.net/forumas/showthread.php?t=3107&page=77 Construction progress] {{DEFAULTSORT:Klaipeda Arena}} [[Category:Indoor arenas in Lithuania]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Klaipėda]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Lithuania]] [[Category:FIBA EuroBasket 2011]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Lithuania]] [[Category:Sport in Klaipėda]] [[Category:FIBA EuroBasket 2011 venues]] [[Category:BC Neptūnas]] {{Lithuania-sports-venue-stub}}
